There is a belief around the Western world that corporations and business will deliver full employment. What absolute rot! How can people think so stupidly? It is the role of government that will look after families. Why would a corporation-a big business or a small business-take on the responsibility of the citizens of a country? That is just absolute nonsense. Why would they? Of course, they would not. They do not have the long-term responsibility for stability in families that governments have. Governments-this government and governments in other parts of the developed worldare moving away at a rate of knots from the commitments and the social contracts that governments should have with battling workers. This legislation is yet another example of the abandonment of public good and the moral contract governments should have with their citizens. It is interesting to note that the leaders government and the leaders of industry around the world in the 1950s and 1960s went through school in the 1930s and the Depression. Many of these people, highly skilled people, waited sometimes three or four years before they got a job. They went through the Second World War, the Korean War and the Cold War, but they believed in the responsibility and were acutely aware of unemployment. Today, the leaders of government, our own generation, and the leaders of business have come from an era of full employment due to the efforts of that previous generation. The sensitivity and the edge for jobs is simply not here. It is something we need to rediscover. It is something that this government should rediscover. If it does rediscover this, then government may have the courage to lead. We might then have ministers on the front bench over there who have the courage to lead. If the government cannot do that and if governments around the world cannot follow their own advice and do not get out of the way, electorates in this country and many other countries in the developed world will very quickly change government in the next 10 years, because the expectations of their citizens are high. So they should be. If governments walk away from their responsibilities, as shown in the Bounty Amendment Bill 1996, they will act at the ballot box far more quickly than people imagine.

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: Corio) (11.09 a.m.)The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 now before the House gives effect to yet another broken promise made by the Howard government before the 1996 election. It joins the long list of broken promises made to Australian industry at that election. This legislation violates the mandate that was given to the Howard government at that election. In the first Howard government budget we have seen the withdrawal of over $3.9 billion in industry assistance over a four-year period. That is in violation of the explicit commitments made to Australian industry in the leadup to that election. For example, the governof ment gave an express and explicit commitment to maintain the research and development taxation concession to Australian industry at 150 per cent. In its budget it announced that it had slashed it to 125 per cent. It gave an express commitment to maintain export incentive programs, and in the budget they slashed them mercilessly. With regard to the bounty schemes relating to books, computers, machine tools and robots, and ships, which are the subject of this legislation, the promises given to manufacturers in these industries have been broken as well. What makes the ahead of schedule termination of the bounty schemes significant is simply the specific nature of the impact of the budget decision-specific in the sense that the impact is on easily identifiable industries and the manufacturing firms and on regional communities. When the government slashed the R&D concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent the impact of that decision was felt by many firms in manufacturing industry. A similar impact has occurred as a result of the reduction in expenditure on export assistance schemes. In the case of the bounty schemes which are the subject of this legislation, the damage wrought by the government decision is localised, identifiable and substantial. While the amendments in this bill represent some marginal improvement on the original measures that were announced in the budget, the opposition regards them as regressive; and we will oppose them. With regard to the government's backdown on the books bounty, we consider that it has not gone far enough with the amendment it is proposing in this legislation. The opposition is of the view that the government should have restored the original expiry date of 31 December 1997 put in place by Labor when it was in government-an expiry date the coalition signed up to before the 1996 election. With regard to the ships bounty, the governof ment backdown extends it six months beyond the 30 June 1996 expiry date put in place by Labor. However, the measures which the government has announced are quite inadequate in meeting the needs of shipbuilders in this country and they have responded to the government's initiative by labelling the government's measures the Clayton's bounty and a failure. The opposition will oppose this government amendment because of its failure to adequately link the bounty to an GECD agreement to eliminate shipbuilding subsidies. The GECD agreement is due to commence in July 1997 but has yet to be ratified by signatory countries. The weakness in what the government is proposing is that it does not provide a sufficient guarantee to industry that the government will extend the bounty if the GECD agreement is not ratified by that date. The opposition's amendment in contrast would ensure the continuation of the ships bounty until the GECD agreement comes into force. This will establish a more secure investment climate for the industry in which it can negotiate its further contracts and get into the exporting ring in a bigger way. This is not the only weakness of the government's bill. The other major weakness relates to the phase-in period. There is an inherent advantage to overseas shipbuilders under the terms of the GECD agreement when compared to what the government is proposing in this legislation with Ian shipbuilders. Under the GECD agreement, shipbuilders can still claim a subsidy up to three years after the agreement commences, provided the contract was signed before that date. Under the government's legislation, the 'bounty can only be claimed for ships completed by the end of 1997. The advantage to overseas shipbuilders is patently obvious. The amendments that the opposition is proposing align Australia's arrangements squarely with the GECD. This at least gives Australian producers the same tilt at industry assistance as overseas shipbuilders. The shipbuilding industry in Australia has left us all in no doubt as to their assessment the government's about-face in this legislation. They still regard the government's measures as a Clayton's shipbuilding bounty, as I mentioned before. I refer the House to a press release issued by the Australian Shipbuilders Association on 12 February 1997. In that press release they explicitly state that this is a Clayton's shipbuilding bounty and that the government's failure to address the bounty issue correctly heralds job cuts and more export losses. At a time when the national economy is struggling and we need extra jobs in manufacturing industry, and at a time when the balance of payments needs exports to bring that deficit down, here we have a deliberate measure being proposed by the government which will, on the advice of the shipbuilders of this nation and other manufacturers who receive the bounty, lead to a decrease in employment opportunities across those industries, particularly in regional areas, and will lead to a decline in exports. This is what the Chairman of the Australian Shipbuilders Association, Mr John Rothwell, had to say: The Australian shipbuilding industry is no better off than it was prior to the Federal Government's announcement to extend the shipbuilding bounty, and substantial stand-downs will be experienced in the near future. Further on he said: While the industry was initially very excited and relieved by the announcement, it has proved to be nothing more than a disappointing teaser, and in reality of no value at all. We remain hugely regard to Australdisadvantaged. This is an industry which employs over 13,000 Australians directly or indirectly and last year earned in excess of half a billion dollars in export earnings. Here we have Mr Rothwell saying that what the government has announced is purely a tease. We have an industry minister who is a big tease. That is about all he can deliver. He does not deliver measures of substance and industry assistance measures of substance; he merely teases the industry while it struggles to compete with heavily subsidised overseas manufacturers in the shipbuilding area. I think it is pertinent at this point to ask why the government is proposing these amendments in its legislation at all. Really, they are simply a humiliating backdown for the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), a minister who is regarded across the length and breadth of manufacturing industry in Australia as both hopeless and hapless. But, of course, the government has changed its view on the measures that it announced in the 1996 budget because of the pressure that we have applied to it here on the floor of this House and out across the regions of Australia. I pay tribute to manufacturers in the industries that are affected by these measures and to the regional communities in which those firms are located for their substantial lobbying efforts on behalf of their workers and their families and their regional communities, because it has been that combination of pressure from the opposition, from regional communities and from industries themselves that has brought this pathetic change-if you can call it thatto the government's proposals. I suppose we should be grateful for small mercies, that the industry minister has gone away and argued the toss before the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and come back with a few concessions to industry. But they do not go far enough. And the only measures and the only amendments that will really address the industry concerns are the ones that have been put on the floor of the House by the opposition. Of course, the government could have saved itself a whole lot of trouble in this particular area, with this legislation, simply by sticking to its election promises. It gave specific commitments to manufacturers in the shipbuilding industry, in the computer industry, in the machine tools and robots industry and in the book printing industry. They were very specific commitments, and those commitments simply said that the government, when and if it came to power, would continue the arrangements that Labor had implemented when it was in power. The Prime Minister also said that those promises were predicated on the basis that, even if there was a deterioration-in the deficit, or even if their worse fears were realised, the bottom line in all of this was that the Prime Minister would keep his promises to the Australian people. Well, he didn't. He didn't keep them to the shipbuilders of this nation or the book printers of this nation. He certainly didn't keep them to the regional communities who are now going to be affected by this exercise in industry assistance stupidity, and certainly not to the workers and their families who are employed in those particular industries. At least we have extracted some concessions out of the government, as a response to the pressure that Labor brought to bear both in this House and out in regional communities. In the context of this debate, I am very pleased to make some comment on the remarks of the Treasurer yesterday when he arrogantly strutted this House claiming that no-one really knew what Labor stood for. This arrogant Treasurer is very much out of touch with what is happening in regional Australia. In Tasmania, they know what Labor stands for in regard to industry policy and the shipbuilding industry in particular. In Western Australia, the shipbuilders know exactly where Labor stands in regard to this element of industry policy. In Maryborough, Victoria-I acknowledge the presence in the House of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who knows the midlands area and that town very well; he should know the devastating impact that the government measures will have on that particular community-they know very well what Labor stands for in regard to the assistance given to the printing industry in particular. We on this side of the House are very perplexed about what this arrogant Treasurer really stands for himself. We know that, as a founding member of the H.R. Nicholls Society, he had very strong views on the course of industrial relations reform, as he calls it-I call it a regressive series of actions with regard to industrial relations-and two, three, four or five years ago we were left in no doubt as to what the Treasurer's views were on industrial relations in this country. The Howard government has brought down its so called industrial relations reforms. The H.R. Nicholls Society has come out in the last week and said that it is a betrayal and a sellout. When asked in this House yesterday whether the Treasurer concurred with the views of this society that he established, all he could say was no-an arrogant no to a very substantial question which was asking the Treasurer where he stood on measures that affect the livelihoods of workers in regional industry. We on this side of the House have very great concerns about the competence of this arrogant Treasurer. The Treasurer is the only economist or chief economist in the Western world that can claim a four per cent growth rate, a two per cent inflation rate, single digit interest rates, low levels of industrial disputathe tion and burgeoning levels of exports and job growth, left to him by the previous Labor government, as an economic mess. We have a real problem in this country when the chief economic officer regards a four per cent growth rate and a two per cent inflation rate as an economic mess. The impact of the government's budgetary measures in the bounty legislation will be felt acutely in the regions of Australia-especially in Tasmania, Western Australia and Victoria. Last year when this measure was announced, I travelled to Maryborough in Victoria-a regional town which relies very heavily for its employment on the printing industry. I talked with industry leaders, community leaders and companies such as MCPherson's which are going to be affected by the withdrawal of the book bounty and the withdrawal of other industry assistance measures that the government is emasculating in its budget. They expressed a total lack of confidence in the industry minister and also in the direction of the government's industry policy. There is one thing that came through in the discussions that I had with those community leaders and particularly with those companies; that is, they require certainty in their investment environment. They made very specific investment decisions and plans on the back of the book bounty and on the back of industry assistance measures that were guaranteed to them by the previous Labor government; and they were given an express commitment by the coalition that those measures would be continued if a coalition government were elected in the 1996 election, regardless of the budgetary circumstance. This twister of a Prime Minister, the honourable member for Bennelong-who goes around this country trying to persuade people that there is such a thing as a core and a noncore promise-violated the mandate that he was given, in the measures that are contained in this legislation before the House. Those people had some very harsh things to say about the industry minister. It is a simple fact that we have a lame duck occupying one of the most significant portfolios in this country. There is no-one on either side of House who can objectively look at the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct and come to any conclusion other than that the industry minister should have been sacked. The only thing that saved him was the fact that two minor heads rolled before the Prime Minister got to consider his particular position and his violation of the ministerial codes of conduct. The Prime Minister's failure to do what he should have done has sent shock waves reverberating throughout regional Australia, because they have lost confidence in this industry minister and they have lost confidence in the industry policy of the government. It is an industry policy that is full of inconsistencies and is in tatters within one year of this government's life. The one thing that has really led to a drop in confidence in the regions has been the downright betrayal of the regions in the measures that were announced in the budget. These measures include the $150 million that was withdrawn from the regional development program; the $620 million that was dragged out of road funding programs; the $1.8 billion that was dragged out of labour market programs; and the cuts to the number of university places which gave regional workers and their children a chance to get a better education-these are the measures that have sapped the confidence of people in regional areas. They have been severely compounded by the measures that are contained in this legislation. I reiterate once again that the industry minister ought to be sacked. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: I am pleased to participate in this debate on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, because I represent Maryborough in central Victoria, which has the highest concentration of printing industries and probably book printers in the whole of Australia. I have represented and have been proud to represent that area since 1976, both in state politics and in federal politics since coming here in 1990. I am pleased to respond to some of the claims being made by members of the opposition. It is remarkable how short their memories are. I can recall that in response to an Industry Commission report in 1992 the opposition, which were then in government, introduced a bill into this House which was going to abolish the book bounty. It was only the serious and strong representations and amendments moved by the member for Barker (Mr MCLachlan), who was at the time the coalition industry spokesman, and me that convinced the government they were heading in the wrong direction at that time. It is all very well for the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) to come into this place and attack me on my track record. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that my track record in the Maryborough area in defence of these industries has been extremely strong. After receiving representations from the Australian Print Group and MCPhersons Book Printer, which are two substantial industries in that area, I have once again opened up discussions with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), and he has given me an undertaking that he will look at the tariff on inputs. I want to refer to this aspect because it is an important part of the debate. A submission that I had from the Australian Publishers Association indicated that the abolition of the bounty would leave the book printing industry in a position of negative assistance unless the tariff on imported paper was removed in parallel. That is what I was referring to when I said I have opened up discussions with the minister, and he has indicated that he will look at a tariff on the inputs into the manufacturing process. I want to refer to the majority report of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. It recommended: ... the Government should amend the tariff regime to address any anomalies resulting from termination of the Bounties, in particular the situation where imported inputs are dutiable but the corresponding imported final goods are duty free. The minority report agreed with this finding. I have made representations to the minister on this matter and the minister has indicated that he will look at that situation. The member for Batman, a comparative newcomer to this House, has easily forgotten the situation that was in place in 1992 after the industry committee report was brought down when his party, which were in government, were going to remove the book bounty. He has simply forgotten all about that. That is removed from his memory-very conveniently, I might add. I can assure the printing industries and also the residents and employees in the city of Maryborough that they have my support on this. In fact, they had my strong support late last year when the government decided to change the termination period of the book bounty. I recall the speech by the minister, who relied on the draft Industry Commission report on book printing in August 1996 which recommended the abolition of the bounty when the current scheme was due to expire on 31 December 1997. The budget legislation speeding up the process of the abolition of the scheme on budget night has been varied with the termination of the bounty now scheduled for 30 June 1997. I had extensive discussions with the minister at the time and I know that he took note of those and that action was taken. For the member for Batman to come in and conveniently forget all about what his party were going to do in government really leaves one in a state of amazement. It seems to be a campaign of the member for Batman to attack both me and the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). He is vigorously going around trying to pick up anything. I want to remind him of what his party did, when in government, to the motor industry. The motor industry in Australia lost 25,000 jobs under the Labor Party government. But I want to strictly stick to the area of the book bounties, because it is extremely important for my area. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I am very keenly aware of it and have been since the build-up of the book industry in the Maryborough area. I might add that my term in state politics probably led to the most major change in industrial expansion in the city of Maryborough that ever occurred. I was able to convince the Hon. Dick Hamer, the then Premier, that Maryborough needed natural gas. During my time as a state member there, the whole city of Maryborough was reticulated with natural gas, and that led to the expansion of industry and employment opportunities in the Maryborough area. There was a substantial growth in industry during that period. In fact, both of the firms I have mentioned-Australian Print Group and MCPhersons Book Printers-have expanded as a result of the availability of natural gas and all the other infrastructure support that is available in the city of Maryborough. They have also been able to attract Nestle, the big sweets and confectionary manufacturer, as a result of natural gas being reticulated through that whole district. I take you back once again to the comments by the member for Batman in this debate and his allegation that I was not supporting the city of Maryborough. I certainly am. In fact, the member for Barker and I, during the debate following the Ie report in 1992, played a major role in overturning the ALP's direction of removing all of these bounties. I find it quite staggering that members from the Labor Party have now conveniently forgotten all about that. The member for Batman also made a number of other allegations about me. One of them was that: There was a commitment to the city of Bendigo prior to the last election which meant a further investment in the form of construction of a new art gallery with additional jobs of benefit to the local community. I want to make one comment on that, Mr Deputy Speaker. The person who made that commitment of $2 million was none other  Keating. He did not deliver on the promise, nor did he put it into the budget estimates. It is very convenient for the member for Batman to be selective about his quotes. He is saying that I, as the member for Bendigo, have gone missing on the question of future book bounties and support for key jobs in the town of Maryborough and his electorate. I can assure you that that is not so. I have been very active on this issue. I have received representations from the Australian Publishers Association. I have made representations to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism and the minister has agreed to look at the situation of tariffs on any inputs into the book printing industry. I thank the House for the opportunity to respond to those scurrilous allegations.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: -I want to approach the issue before the House in a somewhat different way from those of my colleagues, because I think the arguments have gone back and forth. I want to start on the basis that I think there would be a general consensus in this parliament, on all sides, that the biggest single problem facing our community is the problem of unemployment and how we solve it. I do not think we solve it by having a work for the dole scheme, whatever merits or demerits that may have, but we can advance the situation by having a coherent, well thought through policy on industrial development. That means that we look to the development of our manufacturing industry. It is the role of government to consider how it can enhance the existing structures, how it can develop policy which enables the environment in which we live to advance industries in any particular area. It does not really help the argument to get into the sort of exchange, which tends to happen often in this House, where one member says, 'Look what you did. We're going to do the same thing, but we hope we will be able to solve the problem.' If one looks for the reasons for this proposal and where it emanated from, it obviously did not emanate from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) and I do not think it emanated from any of the policy considerations or discussions that took place in the government party meeting. I suspect that where it emanated from was precisely where it emanated from when we were in officeout of Treasury. Part of the problem that the Labor government faced, and I think this government faces, is that Treasury has produced, over a period of time, a group of advisers and senior officers who are committed to the concepts of economic rationalism. The problem with this government is that they, equally, adopt the same ideology. This is the most ideologically driven government that I have seen in all my time in two parliaments. I have some sympathy for the honourable member for Bendigo because the best that he can do is line up with his party to vote for this legislation which will create a problem for an industry in an area that is important to him. The best he can then do is say, 'I'm having discussions with the minister to see whether we can use another device to limit the damage to these industries.' Frankly, with all respect to the honourable member, I do not think that is good enough because the government is facing the same sort of dilemma that people on this side of the House faced when we were in government when in fact a Treasury driven economic imperative does not reach out and look at the problems that confront people in manufacturing industry. If we want to increase employment in this country, if we want to get rid of the spectre of unemployment, then we have to have a coherent economic policy which is directed towards strengthening our manufacturing bases and improving them. I take just one area of Australia which is particularly relevant to my own electorate: development of the shipbuilding industry in Australia is no accident. The contract to build the frigates went to a set of consortiums operating out of Melbourne. Adelaide has produced the technology and the capacity to build the submarine. Cairns is producing the hydrographic ship, and catamarans are produced in Tasmania. Mr Stephen Smith-And Western Australia.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: Western Australia. That was not an accident. It was based on the capacity of those who had the responsibility for running quite large enterprises and their initiatives. But there was government backup and a considered policy. Where is the considered policy here? Where is the considered policy that emerges from Treasury? It says, 'We've been looking at the budget in global.' Let us adopt a policy of reducing bounty exports. Has there been any thought emanating as to the impact that that is going to have-not merely upon an emerging and well-based manufacturing industry? I am not just talking about ships; I am talking also about the printing industry. Has there been any discussion about the ramifications before the government puts this policy in place? What will it mean in terms of jobs in this industry throughout Australia? Who is in a position to advise the government? The people who are in the best position to advise the government are the people in the industry. What do they say? They say that it will lead to further unemployment and a reduced level of manufacturing capacity. Ultimately, it means that Australian industries in this area, in a competitive world, are competing against other nations which have developed skills in these areas over the years and have provided considerable bounties, not merely to attain a technological level of expertise but because they see it is critical to the development of those industries. and to their economic base. What is happening in this country is that, although we are agreed as individuals in this parliament that the greatest social problem the facing this community is the problem of unemployment, we adopt a policy which every member in his heart knows will reduce employment in a key sector of industry. We are going to lend ourselves to the export of jobs to overseas competitors which are maintaining bounties. Does that make economic sense? I suppose it could be argued by the economic rationalists, 'Well, at the end of the day, it'll all be all right.' But they are all right. The people who give this advice to Treasurers-irrespective of governments, because governments in our democratic system come and go-on the basis of their economic theories have never had the responsibility of running a manufacturing industry, never had the problem that confronts people who are operating those industries in Maryborough in my electorate and in electorates all around Australia and never had the difficulty that confronts this parliament as we have a Treasurer (Mr Costello) who shares their economic philosophy. It is an economic philosophy which, in Great Britain, has divided their society, has produced a permanent underclass and produced levels of unemployment and levels of poverty. The government of Great Britain is now facing a massive defeat in the election because the people of Britain will vote against this very system. Do we have to get to a stage in Australia where these sorts of lunatic policies are going to produce that level of social disharmony, that level of social misery, and where an esteemed colleague says, 'Look, I've got to put my hands up for this, but I'm having a bit of a talk to the minister and he will have a look at it'? Does this colleague think, deep in his heart, that when the minister has a look at it he is going to be able to withstand the pressure of those people who are driving these policies in Treasury? I wish him good luck. What this House needs from this government, if it is to keep faith with the electorate in terms of its electoral promises, is an ing and considered, well thought through policy for the manufacturing industries and other areas of economic activity in Australia which are designed to increase unemployment. I believe that there is nobody in this House who believes that, if this legislation goes through in this form, there will not be people losing their jobs, there will not be increasing levels of unemployment-unless the government can find some other way of dealing with it. It seems to me that it is a bit like closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. The Labor government made mistakes in these areas. If we have not learned from the mistakes that we made in the footwear, textile and clothing industries in Australia, we have not learned anything. This government is heading down the same course and it will get the same result. This is ill considered, ill thought out Treasury driven legislation. Isn't a coherent, long-term concept of where we are taking our manufacturing industry and of how we can enhance employment opportunities not only the moral imperative of the government but also the economic imperative? I know that the Treasurer is getting some fairly colourful abuse from an organisation which he founded-the H.R. Nicholls Society. It is all right for the Hugh Morgans of the world-born with a silver spoon in his mouth, never had to face the prospect of unemployment and ushered into daddy's position as head of a major corporation. I do not say that in any sense of personal antagonism: he was very fortunate. But there are lots of people in this society who are not so fortunate. There are lots of kids in my electorate whose father is unemployed or their mother cannot get work and who are forced to live on the dole and suffer all the social consequences that that brings with it-the social tensions and the dysfunctional relati<?nships. I will be voting against this legislation not simply because of my party's position but because it not only involves a serious breach of an electoral promise but more importantly is evidence of the fact that we have not learned from past mistakes. There is nothing ongo- wrong with the government saying, 'Labor has made these mistakes in one industry and we are not going to make it in another.' No government ever gets it 100 per cent right. It is time, given the commitment of this House and the commitment of individual parliamentarians, to deal at a serious level with solving the problems of unemployment in Australia. It is time to look seriously at what is occurring in the many areas of manufacturing which are the core base for future employment and the maintenance of existing employment before we go down the path of saying, 'We are really very good because we are going to adopt the doctrine of economic rationalism and the whole world is our marketplace,' when other competitors like throughout the world, including the United States and many European nations, are not going down the same track. It is a lonely place to be when you confront decent, hard working Australians working in these industries and have to say, 'Oh well, bad luck, although we know that you are likely to lose your job, hopefully we will be talking to another minister and it will not be quite so bad.' That is not an answer. If we are serious about unemployment, and if the government is serious-and I believe most of its members are-about unemployaffected-the ment, we would be adopting policies which puter strengthen our manufacturing base throughout this nation and we would not get ourselves mtothe position which has happened so often where, because of some current economic policy, we finish up exporting jobs. government ought to have a second look this legislation. If it has any commitment its objective of increasing employment, it ought to withdraw it.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: On several occasions in recent weeks the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has taken upon himself to brand us on this side of the House as the forelock tugging Labor. debate whether that is appropriate parliamentary language or not. In any event, it has come from the mouth of the Prime Minister, so it is there. I suppose that expression sarily implies that we have forelocks. That more than I can say for the government this issue. They are completely lacking in necessary anatomy to take up the issues on behalf of Australian industry. They are literalEuropean ly completely neutered when it comes to industry policy. As the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) has just said, they are obsessed with the so-called free market-they almost hold it up as a religious icon. Their one and only philosophy is that, if you get ro-economic settings right, this divine intervention of the free market is going to come and fix every thing up, as if the free market can bestow miracles. Unfortunately, it will not happen, it does not happen like that and it is not happening that in the rest of the world. While ever our government has this view, we are letting our side down and we are very much letting our industry down. As the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) in his speech on this matter said, this legislation will mean a fall in exports, a fall in jobs, a rise in the balance of payments deficit and a rise in the budget deficit. The situation is particularly severe in Western Australia and Tasmania, but in effect it affects all Australians because of the much broader implications across all the industries publishing industry, the comindustry, the tool and robotics industries as well as the shipbuilding industries. Dealing first with the shipbuilding industry, it was reported this week that Austal in Western Australia will dismiss 20 employees The next week directly as a result of the at government's decision. So, like the Red to Baron chocking up kills on the side of his plane, the government can clock up 20 there immediately. Austal has indicated that 100 more employees will go in the next few weeks directly as a result of the government's it decision. Wavemaster in Western Australia has also indicated that 100 employees will go One can in the next few weeks. The facts of the matter are that our European competitors are providing assistance at somewhere between nine and 25 per cent, and necescurrent measures through the OECD to reis move or reduce the assistance provided to on shipbuilding in those countries are being the blocked-substantially as a result 0f United States pressure. But, whatever the reason, the competitors are going to be put in the box seat for at least another 18 months and more likely for two years. The question becomes whether our industry can survive. Unfortunately, the feedback is that it probably cannot survive by staying in Australia. The government is being reckless in the extreme the broad macand irresponsible. It is not as if the shipbuilding industry has got flabby and inefficient under the assistance of the bounty scheme-quite the contrary. Since 1990, its production has increased by 40 per cent. It is now earning well over $500 million a year, and it is confidently predicted that it will be an industry earning in excess of $1 billion per annum by the year 2000. Almost all of that is in exports. Almost all of that is coming off our balance of payments deficit. But, rather than me condemning the government in a partisan sense, as one speaker before me said, they really should look at industry experts. In the Financial Review of 24 January, Mr Clifford-one of those involved in the shipbuilding industry-was quoted as saying: Our industry cannot survive against European competition unless we get some support. In the Australian of 29 November 1996, a Liberal colleague, Mr Court, the Premier of Western Australia was quoted as saying: . . . removal of the 5 per cent bounty would do severe damage to the 'incredibly successful' shipbuilding industry. It is noted in that article that several shipbuilders have already warned that they would be forced to move offshore in order to survive. That certainly has to be an inevitability. It is worth having regard to the comments of an academic-Dr Mark Beeson, research fellow at the Murdoch University Asia Research Centre-because they are an objective analysis in a non-political setting. In an article in the Australian of 20 December 1996, he said: It might be expected that an industry that looked like generating $1 billion in export sales by of the century, and which already directly provides nearly 3000 highly paid manufacturing jobs, might be the subject of a good deal of attention and assistance. Not so-he points outThe light weight aluminium-based fast ferry industry that has produced this remarkable export and job creation performance is to be left to its own devices. As he points out-and consistent with what the member for Melbourne Ports said-these industries did not just happen because of some process of divine intervention or spontaneous production. There was a lot of planning and a lot of strategy that went in-assisted, in many instances, by a partnership between government and industry. As Dr Mark Beeson said: . .. successful industries don't just happen. Without a supportive policy environment that encourages particular forms of strategically important activity, the danger is that such industries may happen somewhere else. That is not only a danger but an actuality. Our competitors realise that. They are well and truly backing their own industries, and they are getting manufacturing jobs. We are letting ours wither on the vine. Indeed, this is worse than allowing them to wither on the vine; it is direct sabotage and vandalism of very successful, highly sophisticated industries conveying very sophisticated skills on to our work force-the flow-on in technologies spreads right throughout industry. To risk losing that, as this government is doing, is nothing short of an outrage. In terms of the government's actions, it is all very well for us in a partisan sense to say, 'They do not understand what they are doing' , but that has also been said by Mr Robert Clifford from Incat in Tasmania. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 22 August 1996, he was quoted as saying: I don't believe the Liberal government understands the economics of the industry. They just don't understand the importanc,? of the bounty to us. That has got to be the case. For them to act as though they have, they simply have not done the necessary research; they have acted the end from a blinkered state. Anyone who cannot see more than one perspective of mind has to be regarded as mentally retarded in that sense. This government's obsessive adherence to this demigod or religious icon-the market force-has, literally, mentally retarded them so they cannot receive the views of industry. Regrettably, we have a government which is mentally retarded because of its ideological straitjacket and our industry is suffering. The member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) referred yesterday to an article in the Financial Review which reported comments by the ASA chairman, Mr John Rothwell. He pointed out to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) that the government's display of beneficence-the extension of the bounty by six months to the end of the year in response to not only Labor pressure but, it has got to be said, pressure from Senator Harradine-is meaningless. As Mr Rothwell says: Minister, it takes 12 months to build a vessel of the car ferry size, which are the majority of exported ferries from Australia. What this means is that presently no shipbuilder can enter into a contract to build a ship with the aid of the bounty, as it will not be possible to complete the ship by the end of this calendar year. I recall the member for Fremantle described how two contracts had been lost because the industry in her state cannot forward plan its contracts because of the removal of the bounty and the time it is going to take to construct the vessels. That is short-sightedness, ignorance and incompetence. - peakers before me in the debate have pointed out that it is poor government in tetins of creativity. The member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) said it is an obsession with short-term debt cutting at the expense of long-term investment. Not only that, they are removing revenue which far exceeds the amount they are paying out in terms of the bounty. That is shown very much in research provided by the Australian Publishers Association with respect to the book bounty. Similar facts exist with respect to the ship bounty where we have received from PA YE tax revenue and payroll tax revenue in the order of $62 million from the ship bounty at a cost of $24 million. So we are well and truly ahead. With respect to the book bounty, the Australian Publishers Association has quantified the decline in PAYE taxation revenue at $9,634,000, a decline in payroll tax revenue at $2,733,000 and increases in unemployment benefits of over $21 million, at a total cost to the government in excess of $33 million, far exceeding the amount the government pays by way of this bounty. The removal of the books bounty six months ahead of time is going to mean the loss of some 1,500 jobs. That is unquestioned. With respect to the seat of Bendigo, Prentice-Hall has for the first time in nine years published a textbook offshore. That is the start of things to come. They were previously doing all that publication in Australia-and a very respected publisher it has become. In terms of the effect on the balance of trade that the loss of the book bounty is going to have, Merino publishers in Brisbane is another example. Merino publishers has obtained contracts to provide to Californian schools all Latino-American textbooks, there being a very big Latino population in California. That state has a population of some 28 million, almost one and a half times that of Australia. The loss of that export opportunity is obvious. In addition, our book bounty has enabled us to be import replacing. Imported books have gone down since 1991 from $400 million to $300 million-and that trend is continuing. As I have pointed out, in terms of the budget deficit we stand to lose more than we will save. Again, there is an obsession with this free market concept. That just is not going to happen. In the case of the book bounty we were actually winning the war against international competition as the Australian Financial Review pointed out on 28 February: The value of Australian book printing in 1995-96 was $270 million, compared with $180 million in South-East Asia. There are very few industries where we are succeeding over our competitors: publishing has been one of them. Again, to cut the bounty off at this time is reckless in the extreme. In terms of the computer bounty, it is already having an effect. The company Netcomm, which is almost a household name-I know on my kids' computer we have a Netcomm modem-is ceasing its production of modems in Australia. That, in this day and age when so many people are connecting to the Internet, is a real tragedy. There is no other description for it. In terms of the computer industry it must be said that trade barriers are coming down, at least in the Asian region. But as a former Labor minister said in November 1995: The computer bounty plays an important role in facilitating investment and value added production in Australia, including the manufacture of essential hardware fundamental to the information age and it is clear that a healthy and broad based hardware manufacturing capability underpins innovative software and services development. There is a rapid trade growing in software and services development and the Asian market, as its economies are improving, presents real opportunities for Australia. The government is turning its back on that opportunity and, again, vandalising another section of Australian industry. In terms of the machine industry-tools and robotics-again the government is short sighted in the extreme. Obviously, if we are going to compete with our Asian competitors, we must do so from the point of view of not technological comparisons but technological superiority. Unless we have that, we will be forced to compete on the lower wages regime. If we want to maintain our standard of living and preserve our wage rates, the only way we can do so is by having the technological sophistication. This move to take away the bounty from the development of our tools and robotics industry is short-sighted. Before it was electsmall ed, the government promised to create 250,000 jobs in manufacturing. You cannot do that unless you build factories; you cannot build factories unless you equip them with tools and technology. Tooling is therefore essential if we want to develop sophisticated tools to equip our factories and if we want to develop the sophisticated robotics technology such as has been at the heart of progress in our car industry. As much as possible we want to tool our factories with these sophistiThis cated pieces of machinery. Unless we do so, it will mean either that our factories do not have those tools or this technology or that they import it from overseas. Again this will have a dramatic effect on our balance of payments. This government has not appreciated that it is all very well being symbolic. It is all well to tell mainstream Australians who are sitting 'comfortably and relaxed' in their living rooms that you are looking after their interests, but if you are not in fact looking after their interests one thing is for sure: will not be too long before Australians see through the bulldust. They do not want to be patronised; they want to see results, they want to see runs on the board. They want to see our manufacturing industries not only matching but beating our competitors. They want to see jobs, and they want to see jobs in sophisticated manufacturing industries. They want the government to have a decent and sustained revenue base from ongoing taxation receipts, not an ongoing liability to pay unemployment benefits. As I have said, this government is short sighted. They are mentally retarded because of their own ideology. They are completely lacking in any courage. Indeed, they stand to be condemned for what they are doing to the Australian economy. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: Like the member for Barton (Mr MCClelland), I am somewhat saddened to rise to speak against the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, as it serves as yet another stark and harsh example of one of the many popular and highly successful programs that the previous Labor government established to support Australia's and medium size businesses which this government is best perhaps described as foolishly dismantling. It also serves as another stark example of the Howard government's duplicitous and misguided treatment of Australia's small business sector. The Minister for Small Business and Con reading speech made quite clear the driving force behind this bill. In the first lines of his speech he stated: bill amends four bounty acts to achieve savings announced by the government in the 199697 budget. A little further on in that same speech he said: The government has decided to terminate the schemes ahead of their scheduled dates . . . because of the overriding objective to eliminate the budget deficit. very I am sure that government members, along with Treasury officials, have a well-known dislike of schemes such as industry bounties which do not accord or fit neatly with their dry economic rationalist view of leaving the it market to its own devices and hang the consequences. This bill is clearly not being driven by any real desire of the government or the minister to establish, as the member for Barton quite rightly contended, viable and long-tenn growth in Australian industry. We are not dealing with this bill because the government in any sense of the word believes that it is part of a broader strategy which may build upon the effective refonns already well under way and entrenched by the former Labor government. However, I do believe that the bill that we are debating here today and the underlying issues involved do indeed go to the heart of the difference between the Labor opposition and the coalition government in both their philosophy and approach to economic policy, and specifically to industry policy. This bill terminates the books bounty, the ships bounty and the machine tools and robots bounty with effect from 20 August last year and, as we have heard other speakers submit, it terminates the computer bounty with effect from I July 1997. Those of us on this side of the House will be opposing this bill on a number of grounds, including its deleterious effects on specific regions of Australia which have become home to these particular industries, the fact that bill represents yet another broken promise by the government and because, last but not least, it is simply poor policy enacted in the shabbiest and most duplicitous of ways. I will go to some detail in regard to each of these bounties. Turning to the books bounty, Australia's printing and publishing companies and their workers have made significant gains in productivity refonn and improvements in competitiveness throughout the course of the last decade. It is unfair and, indeed, unjust to attack in this way an industry that is making such profound progress halfway through its restructuring program merely to satisfy the government's short-term desire to balance the books. As the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) contended, this simply involves a short-tenn desire to cut debt at the expense of long-tenn investment. Indeed, our industries need some measure of certainty. This is an underpinning requirement for confidence before long-tenn investment can be generated. In the case of the books bounty, printing and publishing finns have been operating for some time now on the clear and unequivocal understanding that the measure would be in place at least until the end of 1997. But the government's decision to prematurely end the bounty as of budget day last year makes it very difficult, and perhaps even impossible, for some finns in this industry to make long term investment decisions with any degree of confidence whatsoever. Even the Industry Commission, in its August draft report on the printing industry, recommended that the bounty be allowed to run through to 1997. Of course, the books bounty has had a significant impact on the international competitiveness of both the printing and publishing industries. The export of books, for example, has increased by some 200 per cent over the past 12 years. At a time when the government and economic analysts are calling for measures to deal with the level of Australia's foreign debt, the decimation of the book industry will have a disastrous effect on Australia's current account. According to the Printing Industries Association trade consultant, Mr Ronald Fisher, this surveys by the Printing Industries Association indicate that up to 50 per cent of book production in Australia would be lost to overseas printers with the tennination of this bounty. This would see a loss of book exports up to a value of $40 million to $50 million per annum and an increase in imports of up to $80 million per annum, an adverse impact on Australia's balance of payments to the tune of some $120 million. The ending of the bounty will cut short this growth and significantly reduce employment in the industry. Of course, in the' printing industry, job losses of up to 1,500 have been predicted, with a particularly severe impact upon regional centres such as Maryborough in Victoria, notwithstanding the best efforts of the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). He has, I am sure, spoken long and hard in defence of industries within his own electorate, but that certainly has not been enough to stop companies like Prentice-Hall publishing a book offshore for the first time. The numbers of those in general working in the book and related industries will be cut by almost one-third. I tum briefly to the issue of the ships bounty. We have seen over the last decade the growth of what might best be described as an innovative and export oriented Australian industry in the construction of fast ships and ferries. With the assistance of the ships bounty, companies like Austal Ships in Fremantle and Incat in Launceston have grown from nothing to become major exporters in both the European and Asian markets. The member for Barton in his submission to the House quoted the manager of Incat in Launceston as saying that the government does not know what it is doing in this regard. Maybe he would have a better idea of what the government should be doing had any representative from the government taken the opportunity to visit him during the Liberal Party's national conference in Hobart in the latter half of last year. The abolition of the bounty in this bill will mean that this industry, which has so much potential, will not be able to compete with our international competitors who have subsidies of anywhere between nine per cent and 50 per cent. The Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, in his letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) urging him to reconsider his decision in regard to this particular bounty put the case very clearly and, I believe, very cogently. Mr Court states in his letter: It is inconceivable that this huge export dollar earning industry can successfully survive when competing against subsidies such as those of Norway at 13.2%; Denmark between 8% and 13% and Italy between 15% and 50%. Mr Court goes on to say: Of great importance is the fact that the shipbuilding industry is not promoting hand outs. It can successfully compete in the international market on quality and expertise, but not if it is disadvantaged to the tune of 9% of the contract price. It is only asking that the present rate of 5% be retained until other OECD countries eliminate their subsidies. Prime Minister, I urge you to reverse your government's decision to terminate this five per cent bounty until all other worldwide bounties are removed. It would be a tragedy to destroy what might best be described as the star of Australian manufacturing industries when a small amount of subsidies will ultimately be an extremely good investment for Australia in the long haul. As Mr Court also attested in his letter, the beneficial impact of the ships bounty is clearly significant. Since the bounty's inception, production in the industry has grown by some 200 per cent, exports have grown by 150 per cent and employment levels have grown by 50 per cent. I am sure Mr Court would share similar concerns about the computer bounty, given that there is the genesis of an effective and efficient west coast based computer industry being generated in the Perth area. It was the Labor government who, in 1995, had legislated to extend the operation of this computer bounty right through until the end of the year 2000. During the election campaign, the coalition had matched this commitment. However, in the budget, adding to its ever growing list of broken promises, the government has abolished the bounty from 1 July 1997. Having recently taken part in the debate on the child care amendment legislation, where once again the opposition is in the unusual position of trying to keep one of the government's election promises not to means test child-care benefits, I am not greatly surprised to find another situation where the government is trying to worm its waY' out of one of its election promises. The Industry Commission, in its 1995 report on the computer hardware and software industry, found that firms used bounty moneys effectively, that in the absence of the bounty they may invest less or undertake less R&D and that, for some firms, investment, R&D, exporting and employment would cease without bounty assistance. Although the IC report recommended that the bounty should lapse, this was predicated on the continuation of schemes like the 150 per cent R&D tax concession, the export market development grants scheme and the AusIndustry initiatives, all of which have been cut and slashed by this government. The bounty has been one of a number of measures which have assisted the growth of Australian information industries. Along with partnerships for the development program, the computer bounty has seen information industry exports treble in the last five years.  the Australian Information Industry Association, described the government's decision to hasten the phasing out of the computer bounty as having 'knocked one leg from under the chair of the information technology industry'. I am sure that Mr Upton would have similar sentiments had he been actively involved in the machine tools and robots industry because since the mid-1980s that industry has not become internationally competitive. It has shown an encouraging increase in both production and exports. , For example, in the last three years, Austtalian production of bountiable machine tools tip' mcreased from around $95 million to $-bllflion" when exports have doubled over theÂ·l-e-riod. The Industry Commission, in its draft report on the machine tools and robots industry ,recently recommended that the bounty be retained until its legislated expiry date of 30 June 1997. In scrapping the bounty in the budget, the government has once again shown that it is happy to commission reports and then equally content simply to ignore them. I would like to tum briefly to some comments I made earlier when I spoke of the fundamentally defining nature of this bill and the broader issue of industry policy. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) has moved the following amendment to this bill: ... the House (1) rejects outright the Government's failure to develop and implement a policy for Australian manufacturing industry, and is of the view that because of the inevitable impact this bill will have on employment the bill would be more appropriately referred to as the Bounty Legislation (Export of Australian Jobs) Amendment Bill; ... The former Labor government had a proud record of working hand in hand with industry because we both believed and accepted that there was a strategic role for government to play in working with the private sector to develop our industry potential for the benefit of us all. That role is not about picking winners. It is not a heavy-handed approach. We believed then, and still believe now, that the government has a pivotal role to play in ensuring that the best economic conditions exist in which our businesses can flourish through building a strong and enduring base from which they can branch out into export markets. The MTIA has stated the need for the government to produce an environment for business in Australia which includes a culture which values innovation and success in the global marketplace. Whether through providing high quality infrastructure in transport and communication, through establishing an industrial relations system which encourages both harmony and productivity rather than conflict and division or through simply recognising that the Australian firms have a competitive advantage over their international rivals through their access to and use of technology and innovation, government has an obligation to ensure that the conditions that are necessary for a healthy and growing economy are set in place. This is central to the beliefs of those of us in the Labor Party. That is why we are here in this nation's parliament. Of course, the Liberal Party and those opposite have a diametrically opposed view to the one I have just espoused. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, who is in the chamber this afternoon, knows perfectly well what is at the heart of this bill because in his own words he said 'these measures will help the government to meet the challenge of reducing the budget deficit'. That is what is driving this decision, nothing more and nothing less-and that is the basis for the coalition's approach to industry policy. It is the primacy of the fiscal bottom line. The government's economic policy and philosophy goes no further than the simple and discredited view that the only role for government in the economy is to get out of it, to leave it alone, to let the market prevail. It believes in cutting spending to the bare minimum, privati sing everything and leaving the market to fend for itself. This view is not shared by industry. We have ample evidence of this in their responses to each of the government's proposed changes to measures which support industry. The previous Labor government had a fine record in the development and implementation of sector specific industry policy, and the current government and Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism could learn much from this example. It was the approach through the Button car plan and other similar sectoral industry plans which saw that Labor government achieve real results in reforming and modernising Australia's industry, yet by contrast the coalition's approach is piecemeal and antagonistic. I fear that there is no ample evidence to suggest that the government has no interest in a cooperati ve and strategic approach to industry policy, as it has shown through the crass nature of the measures contained in this bill. The evidence suggests that the government simply has no interest in industry policy or in Australian industry at all. Industry in this country is calling out for a statement of vision. It has not been forthcoming, and it has not been forthcoming because this coalition government has an obsession with short-term debt cost cutting at the expense of long-term investment. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: In summing up the debate on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, I welcome the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) back this morning. Mr Crean-I enjoy working with you.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: Your presence makes my day. We have heard a considerable amount in this debate about how essential these various bounties are to the survival of the firms and sectors that use them. The government has, on a number of occasions, acknowledged the role bounty assistance has played in the development of shipbuilding, books, computer manufacturing and machine tools and robot industries. The fact remains that the actual rates assistance have fallen significantly over years as a result of policies implemented by the previous Labor government. For example, book bounties have fallen from 30 per cent in 1983 to 4.5 per cent from 1 January 1997. The machine tools and robots bounty has fallen from 40 per cent in 1988 to five per cent on 1 July 1996. The industries that utilise the four bounties covered by this bill have been able to adjust. This has been acknowledged by the member for Hotham and by a number of independent reviews. The Industry Commission book bounty review noted, for example, that production of bountiable books had increased over 50 per cent in real terms since 1992 and at a time when the bounty rate was falling. The various reviews of bounties have also found the assistance measures have effectively run their course and should not be extended. Nevertheless, the government has recognised that circumstances do exist which warrant some alteration to the provisions of the existing bill to put in more generous transitional arrangements. For this reason, I will be moving in the consideration in detail stage several amendments to the bill which extend the termination dates for the shipbuilding and book bounties. In conclusion, the government believes that the future of different industry sectors does not lie in debate about the possible long-term retention of low level bounty assistance. Rather the priority is to put in place a more comprehensive framework or strategy for industry that reflects the need to establish an appropriate environment for investment, access to overseas markets and effective business assistance programs. Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: I move government amendment No.1: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (lines 4 to 17), omit the item, substitute: 1 Subsection 4(1) (definition of bounty period) Omit "31 December 1997", substitute "31 June 1997". This amendment and those to be moved as government amendments Nos 2 and 3 give effect to my joint announcement with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 16 December 1996 with respect to the books bounty. These amendments defer the termination date for the books bounty, extending the government's previously announced termination date of 20 August by 10 months. This will better take account of contracts already in place at the time of the August 1996 budget announcement, while preserving a small contribution to the process of fiscal consolidation in 1997-98. I commend the amendments to the House and table the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: The opposition supports the first of these amendtrading ments, the amendment before the House at moment, which in effect deletes the subsection of the Bounty (Books) Act which wound up the books bounty on budget night. We support totally the deletion of this provision from the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. The effect of its deletion will be to restore books bounty in its entirety. That is the position that we want supported in this House. However, I would remind the House that the Minister for Industry, Science ism (Mr Moore) has a further amendment which will restore the books bounty period until 30 June 1997-six months short of the original position. The original position was that the books bounty would remain until 31 December 1997. The first amendment that the government has brought forward is a backto down, but it is only a partial backdown. As result of the campaign that we in opposition ran in the regions-we convinced those in the communities to pursue the campaign-we victory have seen a partial backdown, but the partial backdown does not go far enough. No-one can deny the significant impact that the books bounty has had on the growth of the industry. The industry has increased book exports by 200 per cent over the past years. These are not assistance measures protect industries, they are measures that the playing field. The countries with whom our book publishers must compete all these bounties and other arrangements in place. The level playing field does The reason these bounties were inserted by the Labor government was to enable these industries, which should be world competiis tive, to compete in the marketplace, but they cannot do so because other countries have got measures in place that support their industries. The purpose of the books bounty was to get our book publishers into the game. It is true that under Labor the books bounty would run out by the end of this year but we had undertaken to conduct an inquiry into what should occur post 31 December 1997 . We would have required the Productivity Commission to have regard to two important things in its deliberations: first, the pace of change of our partners; and, second, the impact of the the decision on regions and their jobs. We sought to get the government to accept these amendments when they introduced the Productivity Commission legislation in the last sitting fortnight, but they opposed them. They have no commitment to understanding the what our trading partners are doing. They are expecting our participants in industry to unilaterally disarm and expose themselves to the rest of the world without any support, without any assistance, and to flourish in that and Tourenvironment. It does not happen. We are saying, Minister, that you should not only put this amendment forward but also desist from the further amendments you will be moving. The first amendment will reinstate the books bounty and will enable the inquiry proceed to decide where we go after 31 a December this year, but your next amendment will curtail that. It will end the bounty six months down the track. We have had a partial but we want a total victory. We will be persisting with that view in this House.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: PAIRS
text: I am pleased to be associated with this amendment to the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. It is clear from the lack its of attendance today and the lack of support 12 for the Minister for Industry, Science and to Tourism (Mr Moore) that he is pursuing an level amendment to what is, on balance, a fairly successful scheme. He is not supported today have because the members of his backbench, especially those in regional Australia, know not exist. that they are the real losers. What are the real savings? We are talking about savings in the order of $4 million. That not big bickies according to the current members of the government. Until they were forced to back down because of the results of the polling conducted by Andrew Robb, they were prepared to move the Speaker's chair at a cost of $500,000. That $4 million is not big bickies in the mind of the minister for industry-after all, in terms of his lifestyle, it is not even worth a big drink. That is what he is on the record as being concerned about. It goes to a question of the impact of these proposed changes on regional Australia. Yesterday afternoon, in the debate concerning this all-important bill, I raised the question of the impact on regional Australia. It goes to a question of a fairly fundamental issue-jobs. I find it strange that the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), for example, is not here this afternoon speaking in support of the amendment moved by the shadow spokesperson for industry. If anyone ought to be on his feet at the moment, rather than cowering in the corridors of Parliament House, it is the member for Bendigo. He ought to be in here this afternoon standing up for the town of Maryborough. In case the member for Bendigo does not know, Maryborough is in his electorate-it is not in Queensland, it is actually near the town of Bendigo. Twenty-five per cent of the work force in Maryborough depends on the book industry through two key employers. Worse still, it is an area of high unemployment. It is an area that demands government assistance. It is an area that is prepared to stand on its own two feet, provided the government has a well thought out industry policy which creates opportunities for that town. Twenty-five per cent of that townwhich covers quite a considerable number of families-depends on the bounty system. As I said, the people of that town are prepared to stand up and be counted. They are prepared to deliver. All they are asking for is a helping hand in accordance with the original proposal with respect to this bill. Instead, they will suffer as a result of the initiatives of the minister for industry. They will suffer a full frontal attack on the welfare and livelihood of that town. One-quarter of the local work force is dependent on this bill. Two big printing firms-the Australian Print Group and MCPherson's Printing Group-are central to that local economy. That might not mean much to the minister for industry, because I dare say he has not got shares in those two companies, but it means a lot to the livelihood of that town. The government ought to embrace this amendment. It is not big bickies, it is not even a big drink in the mind of the minister for industry-it is $4 million. However, in terms of that town it is big bickies-25 per cent of the work force. I can understand why the minister for industry is feeling the pinch this afternoon. They might not be game to come here, stand up and speak about the importance of this bill, but out on the back bench they are vitally concerned. If I were the member for Bendigo I would be concerned about an unemployment rate of 10.5 per cent. I would be concerned about the potential job losses from the impact of ripping away additional assistance for a very short period in a town of high youth unemployment, a town that needs government assistance, an area that is already suffering from high unemployment, an area that is crying out for a reasonable industry policy approach. On balance, it is about time the government took up what was a fairly objective criticism by the former chief executive officer of the Metal Trades Industry Association. Everything is not a cost, it is an investment-it is about investment in industry and investment in regional Australia. Embrace the amendment, look to the future, and support regional Australia where it requires assistance. Support industries that have proven themselves capable of growing on the export front and, in so doing, create additional jobs. Do not run away from your responsibilities, face up to them. Embrace the amendment before us, support regional Australia, and vote for jobs in regional Australia.

Title: PAIRS

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
