Let the member for Bendigo understand that he is voting against jobs in Maryborough today. He is voting against jobs in his electorate. He is betraying his electorate. He is betraying them because he is not prepared to stand up in this chamber, stand up to you, stand up to that ideologically driven front bench, and stand up to the Treasurer. Minister, we know that you want to stand up to the Treasurer (Mr Costello). You relish the fact that you can beat him in these little debates from time to time because we know you do not like Victorians. You are a Queenslander in the Liberal Party and you do not like Victorians. He does not like them. He is on record as saying he does not like the Victorians, so any time he can beat the Victorians, he loves it. Here is your chance to do the Treasurer. You get two hits at once, you get jobs in Maryborough for your friend in Bendigo and you also do your Treasurer. Why won't you stand up for Australian industry? Why won't you support jobs? Why won't the member for Bendigo come into this House and support the people of Maryborough? The fact of the matter is he is running scared. He is not prepared to stick up for the people of Maryborough and they will remember that at the time of the next election. Let me say to you, Minister, what the industry has said about your decision. MCGraw-Hill, one of the largest book publishers in this country, said that there is no doubt that substantial damage has already been done since the budget announcement of 20 August. They go on to thank the Labor Party for the support they got from us in having this decision partially reversed. But what you need to do is to fully reverse it because what you have done is to cause damage which can only be repaired if you enable the industry to get back to a position in which it can have full opportunity to plan, to invest, to get the jobs back in this industry in a way that continues to trend. The real problem for you, Minister, is this. You have a target of 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing but you are introducing policies that will see jobs disappear. They have already started to disappear and they will disappear because you are dismantling programs that saw the growth of jobs in the manufacturing industry. One quarter of the work force of Maryborough is at risk here. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: PAIRS
text: Here is a real chance for the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) to draw the line. We read in the paper from time to time about his so-called industry policy . We also read in the paper from time to time about his desire to stand side by side with industry to make sure that not only are they capable of growing on the export front, but also capable of increasing job opportunities in Australia. But the problem is that every time there has been a fight in cabinet to date he has thrown the towel in. He has only been forced to make some concessions as a result of a huge community campaign where the impact has been too high for the government to suffer with respect to their potential electoral prospects. That is why, for example, some changes have already occurred with the bounty legislation. I take the view that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism is not associated, in his heart, with the anti-jobs group that is running the cabinet at the moment. He does not want to be associated with people such as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) who have no concerns for mainstream Australia. Under it all, he accepts the need for an industry policy. That is what he keeps telling all the industry groups about. That is why he keeps giving them, under the lap, a campaign strategy to take on the Treasurer and his cohorts in cabinet, the anti-jobs group that dominates cabinet at the moment. We are lucky. Some of the opposition have been able to get hold of that strategy about where the pressure points are and who you have to pressure to achieve a change in government policy to protect industry and to protect jobs. I am saying to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism today, 'Look my friend, look my mate, we are with you,' but you have to have a bit of Dutch courage. Maybe we ought to have this debate after lunch, then you can come back in here reinforced with a desire to fight on-to go for the jugular, to stand up for Australian jobs, to stand up for industry and to stand up for Maryborough because you need a helping hand. I think you want to win, but in some ways you have adopted the view, 'I am in my last term of parliament. I have proven that I can be a minister again.' With all due respects to the minister, it is not just about the perks and lurks of a ministerial officer; it is really about delivering out there for mainstream Australia. What they are concerned about-I am sure their polling is showing this-is a sense of security with respect to jobs and their ability to look after their families. The minister has to take a stand. He has lost all the fights to date on industry policy. What happened to the tax incentive for research and development? Lost that fight. What happened to the export market development grants scheme or the development import finance facility? Threw the towel in again. Stand up and be counted. Support our amendment on the books bounty. Do something about jobs in regional Australia. Do something about our young people. Say to the member for Bendigo, 'Look, don't hide in the comer any longer. Come in here, exercise a bit of courage and put your hand up.' Cross the floor and vote for your local community; cross the floor and vote for the security of the 25 per cent of jobs that exist in Maryborough; cross the floor and vote for companies which have a proven track record of being able to deliver the goods, deliver exports and deliver jobs. That is what it is about. Don't be part of the anti-jobs group that is dominating cabinet at the moment. It is not in your heart. You know better. Embrace the amendment. Adopt a bit of Dutch courage. If you want, we will delay the debate until after lunch so that you can come in here reinforced with the desire to fight. The coalition's abolition of the books bounty six months ahead of its expiry date is wrong. It potentially means 15,000 job losses with a particularly severe impact on regional centres. In all seriousness, this is an amen 0ment that ought to be seriously considered. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism knows it in his own heart. Stand with us. Vote for regional Australia. Vote for jobs and vote for industry that has a future.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: We have already indicated that the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), if he has a conscience at all and if he has the interests of his constituThat ency at heart, should be voting with us on this Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. But there is another that should be voting with us, Minister: the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes). The problem is that jobs have been lost in South Australia as a result of this ridiculous decision of the government to axe the books bounty. Three hundred jobs have been lost at Griffin Press as a result of the decision you took on budget night. It is not just us expressing concern about the ideological drive that is taking you forward in this way, your inability to win an argument in cabinet. You really support us. That is why you are out there having meetings with the textile industry, telling them, cannot win an argument in cabinet. Cabinet is full of dries. I am the only wet amongst those dries.' He goes along to these meetings and says these things: 'I will tell you what to do. We will get a campaign running. I will help you in this campaign because we have really got to do these fellows in Treasury. We have really got to do these ideologues, because I am on your side.' But the trouble is that he cannot stand up to the people in cabinet. He cannot win an argument in cabinet so he has to resort to cloak and dagger stuff to try to get support for his positions. Three hundred jobs lost in Griffin Press in Adelaide, and what did the member for Kingston have to say about it? Very interesting if you read the Advertiser of today, which says with regard to the member for Kingston: The Member for Kingston, Ms Sue Jeanes, yesterday urged the Government to be more critical of the advice it received in preparing its second Budget. She said cuts to industry assistance in last year's Budget had already hurt the State ... and any further cuts could destroy the local economy. "Economic rationalism is becoming our nation's newest form of cancer," she said. But she said the Government's focus on fixing the economy needed to be balanced by a commitment to spending money on jobs and industry-" ... governments have a very legitimate role to play in supporting industries, and we haven't focused on our manufacturing sector enough. is under today's date. That is the member for Kingston. That is another one of your backbenchers who is not in this chamber today. She is prepared to go to the press and get a headline but she is not prepared to vote for South Australia in this chamber. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) will not stand up for the workers in Maryborough and now the member for Kingston wants to get a story in the paper expressing concern but will not support the policies that will help the people in her state. That is why I say that they are hypocritical. They know that what the Labor party is pursuing on these issues is correct. They know that they should be supporting our 'I amendments. They are hoping that pressure can be kept on this government to reverse its decision even further, but they have not got the courage to vote with us in this chamber. They are the people that claim that they vote for and represent constituencies but they are hidebound by the rigidity of their position and not allowed to vote as they really believe that they should. The fact of the matter is that industry policy under this government is in chaos. It is in chaos because the member is incapable of articulating a vision. In fact, listening to him on a lot of things, I think he is incapable of articulating anything. But he is certainly incapable of articulating a vision for manufacturing industry. Not only has he been condemned by every industry group in this country, but he has now got lO of the top chief executive officers of the country condemning the lack of vision and the lack of support for industry. The fact of the matter is that this decision today that he is putting forward is another nail in the coffin for one of Australia's successful manufacturing industries. It is a nail in the coffin for regional development; it is a nail in the coffin for jobs in Maryborough, in Geelong, in Adelaide-and you do not care. The problem is that you have made a commitment to getting jobs but you are introducing policies that will see them disappear. The Labor Party will oppose the amendment that you are putting forward, Minister, because it is the wrong decision. It breaks promises, it is unsoundly based and, most of all, it is anti-regions and it is anti-jobs. It will not support the manufacturing industry in this country which has grown so significantly because of the policies that Labor had in place. We oppose the amendments and call on those on the other side who say they share a belief in this view to join us in so opposing. (Time expired) Item 1 omitted.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: PAIRS
text: This is the most important part of this amendment because it reduces the period for this bounty back six months. For the paltry sum of $4 million, this government is going to place in jeopardy many jobs in the printing industry and the fact is that there has been no argument put in this debate. No argument has been put by the minister in this consideration in detail stage about any rationale for not keeping the bounty until 31 December 1997. There has been no attempt by the minister to give any full explanation of why that is so. He relies on the joint press release he made with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) but that has no explanation of why the bounty period is to be reduced by six months. Here we have an argument in this chamber over bringing the expiration of the bounty back from 31 December to 30 June 1997. As my colleagues, the members for Hotham (Mr Crean) and Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), have indicated, what the minister has to understand is the regional consequences of the decision that his government is involved in. We have acknowledged that perhaps these are decisions that do not rest easy with him, perhaps these are decisions for which he argued a different case and lost but the simple fact is that on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill-the original bill-the only basis for it was as part of the budgetary strategy of the government for fiscal consolidation. I see the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) in the chamber. Perhaps he has been flushed out by the efforts of the honourable members for Hotham and Batman but perhaps he will take this opportunity to tell us how he is going to defend the workers of Maryborough. It is important in this debate that a member like the member from Bendigo comes before us to defend those workers from Maryborough that are likely to lose their jobs. The thing that we wish to see is the response from the minister on this point. He sat there, babbling away, interjecting, not putting any concrete case to justify either the original decision or the ensuing backflip. Why is the six-month period so important? Obviously it is only important because of the budget bottom line and the $4 million that it is likely to save in the budget. That is just not good enough for the people of Maryborough where the printing industry employs something like 25 per cent of the township's employment force. They need answers from the government about the alternatives. What are the alternatives? Simply put, the overall macro settings that they rely upon have not eventuated into jobs. What the Australian community is looking for is Australian jobs. This is an argument about Australian jobs. What we need to see from the minister today is some indication of what it is that he is arguing in cabinet against those cabinet ministers who are from the dry faction of his party and are very much anti-job. What the minister needs to understand is that these policy matters are complicated. In the Australian Financial Review of Friday, the Australian Publishers Association put a proposition. The Australian Publishers Association's proposition was based on the fact that the cost to the budget of the government's policy is likely to be $28.6 million over 12 months based on the lower tax revenue and the higher unemployment. Unfortunately, that association's solution is to ask that the tariff on imported paper should be removed at the same time that this bounty is decreased. Which state would be most affected if this tariff was removed? Which state would be the most affected? Tasmania. So, in juggling the regions we are going to trade one region off against another. This is the whole problem. When the Productivity Commission legislation was before us and the opposition said that the Productivity Commission should take into seat. account the regional aspects of policy ideas, the Minister denied that that should be part the Productivity Commission's considerations. The survival of the regions is dependent on this. (Time expired)

Title: PAIRS
text: Order! The honourable member for Hotham, resume your

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: PAIRS
text: I am pleased that the member for unemployment-I should say the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid)-has found his way into the chamber! The member for Bendigo has just returned from viewing the art galleries of New York, and yet he has walked away from a promise given to the electorate of Bendigo prior to the last election to construct an art gallery in Bendigo. The people of Bendigo cannot go to New York to look at art galleries. The art gallery that was promised to them by the member for Bendigo is still in never-never land. The real question is: will the member for Bendigo vote against this bill? Will the member for Bendigo stand up for local jobs? If he does not vote against this bill the simple message to the electorate of Bendigo will be that the member for Bendigo is guilty of destroying local jobs. That is what it is about. It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for his electorate. It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for local jobs. It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for the town of Maryborough. I know he wishes that the town of Maryborough were in Queensland, but it is in his electorate. For the member for Bendigo-and I know he likes to occupy the chair-it was not a great issue moving the Speaker's chair from Old Parliament House to this House at a cost of $500,000. I put it to him that to vote with us will effectively mean that an additional $4 million this financial year will be allocated giving assistance, especially to jobs, in regional Australia. I believe that the member for Bendigo ought to stand with us. I am more concerned with jobs in Maryborough than jobs offshore in Indonesia or the Philippines. That is what we are really talking about. Are we going to have jobs in Maryborough, Bendigo, Ballarat, Townsville, Cairns and Dubbo, or are we going to give jobs to Indonesia and the Philippines? That is what you are voting for today. That is what you will be guilty of if you vote with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore). What the member for Bendigo has got to think about is whether to vote for jobs for Australians or for jobs offshore. There is only one way he should vote. He should vote against the government. He should cross the floor and stand side by side with the electors of Bendigo. It is important, not just because of the jobs that are part and parcel of the town of Maryborough and the book industry, but the real problem the government has to consider is the multiplier effect that those jobs create in the local region. Jobs in those towns are more important than jobs in Indonesia or the Philippines. The book bounty has a multiplier effect in the economy in the order of 13 times the initial outlay. It is not a cost, it is an investment-13 times the return for the initial outlay. Even the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism would consider that a pretty good investment! We know he is not a bad investment manager. Maybe he ought to think about investing in these plants. I am sure that would give him a bigger return than some of the blind activities he is now conducting in the share market through some of his mates. Unemployment of the order of 10.5 per cent in Bendigo is intolerable. The member for Bendigo ought to stand up and be counted. He ought to be the voice of the town of Maryborough. He ought to be prepared to stand up and say that youth unemployment is a major problem in his electorate. He ought to be prepared to say that he is concerned about the chronic loss of jobs in his electorate. He ought to walk down View Street and to say, 'I am going to fight,' rather than write yet another letter. I understand he has just about run out of stamps. He writes a lot of letters, but he cannot put up his hand when it comes to voting. I am prepared to vote for an additional stamp allowance so that he can write a few more letters, but on this occasion he should put his hand up and vote with his feet rather than run away from his responsibilities! It is all about voting with your feet and standing up for your electorate, not writing letters. The member for Bendigo should be voting for the art gallery in View Street, Bendigo. He should be voting for the book bounty so there are jobs in Maryborough. He should be voting to reduce unemployment, which is over 10 per cent in his electorate at the moment. He should be voting for regional Australia. He should be voting for families. He should not be running away from his responsibilities, as he has consistently done since he was elected to this parliament in 1990.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: PAIRS
text: I welcome the opportunity to respond to the challenge from the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). As a member of the ACTU, the member for Batman was running away at 100 miles an hour when the Whitlam government was abolishing tariffs, and he was remarkably silent on the book bounty when the book bounty legislation came before this House in 1992. There was not one word on behalf of the workers whom he was supposed to represent. When you think back to that 1992 legislation as a result of the Industry Commission report, it was not worth one word in their defence. It is all very well for the member for Batman to raise a whole range of other issues. He raised the Bendigo art gallery. The only person who promised $2 million to the gallery  the time. And what did he do? Did he provide a dollar? Not one lousy dollar did the former Prime Minister provide. Nor did he put it in  made this promise, he was actually the Prime Minister and in control of the Treasury. I want to get back to the bill because the allegation from the member for Batman is that the book bounty should be retained. I put a proposition to the minister and the minister has agreed to look at it. That is more constructive than the ALP has been. The proposal I put to the minister was put to me by the Australian Publishers Association who believe that there should be a correction on the other side of the ledger that would be related to the tariff on inputs into the industry. The minister has given an undertaking that he will look at that situation and I will be anxiously looking towards what outcomes that provides. I can assure the House that this is sheer hypocrisy on the part of the Labor Party. After all of their years of cutting tariffs one after the other while supposedly looking after the employees in various industries, just remember that 25,000 jobs were lost in the motor industry during that time. And now you come out and try and make some capital out of this. The minister has taken note of the comments I have made on tariffs on inputs. I will be monitoring that situation on behalf of two very important industries in my electorate.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) writes the letters. He is the new Alastair Cooke, Letters from America-not letters from Bendigo, letters to the minister from New York. When the member for Batman was talking about View Street, he got out the old New York street directory because he had been so used to traipsing around there getting used to his new lifestyle that he had forgotten about Maryborough. Let me just come to some of the issues that the member for Bendigo has raised. He talks about the loss of memory and about the fact that I, in this House, supported a resolution to abolish the books bounty. I think that this is what he was inferring, although he never quite stated it because he did not know what he was talking about. In 1992, the Labor government did propose the abolition of the books bounty. But it did not do it and do you know why? The member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) and the member for Hotham were in there saying, 'Don't do it,' and it was not done. That is why the book bounty exists. I say to the member for Bendigo that if the book bounty had been abolished, why would we be up dealing with it today? The only people seeking to abolish it are the Liberals, aided and abetted by the member for Bendigo. The question of the art gallery in Bendigo is really getting under the guard of the member for Bendigo. You try to say that the former Prime Minister promised the $2 million. He did, but so did you. You went to the press and said, 'We need to be able to match this promise.' You promised them $2 million. Do you know what? He then got the Treasurer (Mr Costello) out, and the Treasurer said, 'We are not going to give you that $2 million but we will fund a feasibility study and we will give you $100,000.' This is the Alan Bond solution. This is payment of 5c in the dollar. That is your treatment of the electorate of Bendigo. That is your approach. You promised them $2 million, and you gave them $100,000. You are a disgrace. You are a disgrace to the electorate of Bendigo, because you will not stand up for them. I make this further point. You talked about what Labor did in 1975 and did under the tariff plans that Labor introduced for textiles and clothing. None of the companies that we visited the other day-Empire Rubber, Stafford Ellinson, ADA-would have been in existence had it not been for Labor's automotive and textile plans. You go and talk to them. Your problem is that it is a bit expensive to make the long distance phone call from New York, and they will not pick it up, in your case. You are irrelevant because you cannot do anything for Bendigo. You cannot deliver the art gallery. You cannot deliver jobs in Maryborough. You cannot support the ongoing plans for the automotive industry. Go and talk to the component facturers. Go and talk to BTR-who run Empire Rubber, in case you did not know. Go and talk to Stafford Ellinson. Go and talk to the Australian defence establishments who have introduced state-of-the art clothing, have invested in technology and in the future, and who have actually made a commitment the region based on the certainty that our tariff plans produced. We understood importance of reducing tariffs to make internationally competitive but we also stood the importance of getting companies into overseas markets. In other words, our market is too small Australia. The market that we have got to participate in is the global market, but cannot do that by dismantling tariffs unilaterourable ally and giving no support to get into exports. That is what our approach on industry policy is. That is what you have dismantled, and is what the books bounty has dismantled. That is why jobs are threatened in Maryborough. That is why, unless you back our positiontion the majority position-in terms of cars, the jobs at Empire Rubber will be threatened; that is why, if you go down the same crazy route in terms of textiles and clothing, Stafford Ellinson and ADA will be under threat. I ask you, as the member for Bendigo, when are you going to stand up for your constituency? Are you in retirement now? I can see you jumping to your feet. Why did you only take 10 minutes? I have still got a bit more time, and I will have some more. Why did you go to New York when this issue was on? Why did you desert the constituency, and why will you not cross the floor on this amendment? If you have got any commitment to Bendigo, you will vote with us. If you do not, you are only going to betray them.

The overall effect of the bill that we have before us is to drive Australian jobs offshore; to drive the jobs of those in Maryborough that are working in the print industry offshore to our neighbours in the Asian region. The proposal now being put as a solution to save the jobs of those in Maryborough is to deny the jobs of those in Tasmania. Perhaps there is some forgetfulness in the people that are proposing this, like the honourable member for Bendigo, in that they need to be reminded that, whilst Tasmania might be overseas, Tasmanians' jobs are Australian jobs. We have people like the honourable member for Bendigo who represents a regional centre in Victoria. We have the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr MCArthur) who has an interest in the important regional centre of Geelong. I hope that their submissions to government take into account the effects of the policies of this government on the regions. As the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) indicated, when the proposal was made earlier by a Labor government to remove the book bounty it was consideration of the impact on regional Australia that led to the decision not to go forward with the removal of the bounty. This government seems incapable of understanding that the directions of their policies have to take into account the impact of those policies at the regional level. If one looks at the month to month unemployment figures-and this debate is about jobs, Australian jobs, keeping them in Australia not driving them overseas-the government needs to take into account the regional impacts. We have somebody here from the National Party prattling on about opportunism. There is no opportunism in my position. My interest is the jobs of Australians. That is the paramount consideration. The issue before us in this consideration in detail stage is to ensure that the book bounty continues through to 31 December of this year. At no stage in this debate has there been any justification for removing the bounty after the end of June, because the only justification is the saving of $4 million to the budget bottom line, totally ignoring the impact on employment, especially in regional Australia. Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Recognising that economic development will lead to further job creation, what is the government doing to facilitate an increase in major investment projects in Australia? In particular, what initial steps is the government taking to ensure major national projects are not held up by unnecessary departmental delays?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Since coming to office, the government has followed a coordinated strategy to encourage major investment projects in this country. We have followed policies which have created fiscal and monetary settings which give confidence, encouragement and hope to major investors in Australia. We have set about the process of reducing the cost of doing business in this country. We have passed, after some obstruction from the Labor Party and, initially, from others in the Senate, the Workplace Relations Act, the provisions of which are progressively coming into operation. They provide a far better, a more beckoning and a more benign climate for major projects in this country. The provisions of that act are far more likely to encourage people to invest in this country than did the old industrial relations regime which the new Workplace Relations Act has replaced. We have also set about reforming elements of infrastructure in this country in electricity, gas, water and telecommunications. We have strongly promoted the national competition policy and, of course, we have foreshadowed essential reforms in the area of waterfront and shipping. Some of those reforms have occurred already and others will be tackled during the course of this year. Importantly so far as regional Australia is concerned, we have acted to create certainty of access in some of the resource industries. We have begun and successfully concluded the negotiation of an agreement in the Gippsland area so far as forests are concerned, we are grappling with the difficulties thrown up by the High Court decision in the Wik case, and we have set about rationalising Commonwealth-state responsibilities in environmental policy in order to reduce compliance costs. It is very encouraging to note that business investment in this country has grown by no less than 20 per cent during the past year. As foreshadowed in my statement to parliament at the end of last year, I have established a part-time consultancy position in my office for somebody who will act as a facilitator of major projects. I am delighted to confirm that Mr Bob Mansfield will fill that position. Mr Mansfield is a former Managing Director of Optus, a former Chief Executive with the Fairfax organisation, and he recently carried out a review of the functions and the charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. He will serve as a part-time consultant attached to my office on the basis of established conditions which have applied to part-time consultants employed by former Prime Ministers. It is anticipated that he will devote, on average, two to three days a week to his new task. His appointment will be for an initial period of 12 months, with scope for extensions if that is the mutual desire of myself and Mr Mansfield. His major task will be to bring about the speedy approval of major nation-building investment proposals which conform with government policy. For the first time, the federal government of this country will have at the elbow of the Prime Minister somebody with strong business experience with a specific brief to cut through the red tape which so often holds up, delays, frustrates and, in the process, destroys jobs that can be created by the coming into being of major investment projects. Our commitment to improve the climate of operation for small business in this country is undoubted and undiminished. There is also a very major role in the future of Australia's economy for the development of major projects attracting large levels of investment, both domestically and from overseas. We need a heightened, more concentrated effort to sweep away the obstruction, the bureaucratic delay, the red tape, the unnecessary obfuscation which is often involved in the process of government approval and determination. I believe Mr Mansfield's appointment will strike a very strong blow in that direction. NA

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for MCMillan for his question. Today, the national accounts showed a 0.5 per cent growth for the December quarter and 3.1 per cent over the course of the year. I note that there were substantial revisions to each of the preceding quarters, including the last quarter of September, although it was the March 1996 quarter that was substantially revised downwards. One of the principal detractions from growth in the December quarter was around one per cent, as a result of strong imports. As I said in the House yesterday, the strong imports were not altogether a bad thing, coming as they did from intermediate and capital goods. What they do, in relation to imports of intermediate goods, which in the quarter increased by 7.7 per cent and capital goods of 4.5 per cent, is to lay down the basis for good investment and good growth over the future year. Taken with more up-to-date indicators, including a very strong rebound in retail trade of 2.7 per cent in January and leading indicators in the housing sector, which show building approvals rising-as I referred to in the House yesterday-what this shows is strengthening growth throughout 1997, low inflation, high business investment, good capital imports and the opportunity, with lower interest rates cutting in over the course of this year, for growth to strengthen throughout the course of 1997-98. Since March 1996, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has reported 160,000 new jobs in Australia and, on an adjusted basis, there could in fact be up to 200,000 jobs created over the period. The member for MCMillan also asked about the implications for the regions of Australia. In relation to his area, the regions of Australissues is, he would know that it has been this government's stand in relation to forest and forestry agreement which has given wonderful job opportunities which were denied by our predecessor governments down in his area. He would also know that, over the course of this year, this government will put in place the most exciting environmental development Australia has ever seen--opposed by the Labor Party, I regret to say-and put in place by a government that is concerned about the environment; a $1 billion environmental trust to rebuild the environment of Australia. It is something that this government, I believe, and this Prime Minister, if I may say so, will be able to look back on in decades to come and say that the government in 1996 had the courage to put this trust together-one of the most long-sighted environmental developments that we have ever seen in this country and, I regret to say, opposed by the Labor Party root and branch at every step that we took to put in place this environmental trust. That will be of enormous benefit, I believe, to the regions of Australia as we go about rebuilding the infrastructure, as we go about revegetating Australia and as we go about cleaning up the rivers. The member for MCMillan, I believe, will be proud that his electorate has been treated so well by a visionary initiative of this government which will grow and prosper for decades to come. Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of recent media speculation in relation to the sales process for Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane airports? Minister, what stage has the sale process reached and what is the next stage?

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his question. There have been a number of recent media reports in respect of the sale process for the long-term leases of Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports. I am pleased to say that we have received a total of 18 individual, strong, competitive and high quality bids from nine consortia. Each of those bids has been thoroughly reviewed by the asset sales team, which includes BZW-the government's advisers-against a comprehensive set of evaluation criteria based on the government's stated sales and ongoing privatisation objectives. The long-term lease of airports will maximise efficient airport operations and it will facilitate future airport development on a commercial basis. The evaluation criteria for the bids included the price, ownership diversity, contribution to regional development, airport management capacity, airport development plans, awareness of environmental issues and consideration of the interests of the stakeholders of these airports, including the customers and local and state governments. Following that extensive and exhaustive evaluation process, the government, as flagged as an option in the tender documentation issued to the bidders, has decided to leave 13 individual bids, from six of the bidding consortia, on the table for the next stage of the process. Revised bids from the short-listed bidders for one or more of the airports are to be submitted by mid-April following access to due diligence information and meetings with the government sales team. Completion for each airport is expected to be undertaken in sequence. The sequence will be determined after receipt of the revised bids. I acknowledge the contribution in this process made by the opposition, particularly by the former Minister for Finance, the now Leader of the Opposition, who actually commenced this process. We all know that he was a strong supporter of privatisation when he was the Minister for Finance. I am not so sure that new Labor shares the same support that the Leader of the Opposition formerly gave. I noted that the honourable member for Melbourne in a recent speech to CEDA made it very clear that he had a different view from what old Labor's view on privatisation was. I sincerely hope that his view does not come through in the end. I am confident, however, that over the next few months we will draw the sale of the first phase airports to a very successful conclusion in the interests of the people of Australia. High Court

Human Cloning

Speaker: Mr FORREST
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the announcement by President Clinton that the US government will not be approving funds for research involving human cloning experimentation? Can the minister confirm that human cloning experimentation is currently not permissible in Australia under National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines? Will the government ensure that these guidelines remain in place?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been very substantial interest in newspapers and magazines over recent weeks in this issue after the announcement that, at the Roslin Institute in Scotland, a sheep had been successfully cloned. Cloning is nothing new. It was first achieved in 1952 in tadpoles. But what is new is that it has been successful in higher animals. Two days ago it was announced at the Oregon Primate Research Centre in the United States that a monkey had been successfully cloned and it was on the basis of this that President Clinton announced overnight that federal funding would not be available for research into human cloning. He was responding to a situation that exists in the United States. The situation in Australia is different, as I will outline in a moment. Of course, the problem for society is that the technology of cloning and its experimentation are progressing at a much faster rate than that at which society can contemplate the scientific, social or ethical implications of such experiments. It has been given more urgency because the cloning of a primate is get something very significant as it is the species most close to the human race genetically. It is very difficult to contemplate what the long term prospects might be. The situation in Australia basically has three points to it. The first is that, under NHMRC guidelines, human experimentation with the aim of producing two or more genetically identical offspring, which is in fact cloning, is prohibited. The NHMRC has the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a subcommittee which has published ethical guidelines on assisted reproductive technology. These were tabled in parliament in November last year. The NHMRC is of the view that such experimentation is unethical. It would not be funded under the National Health and Medical Research Council. The other great body of funding in Australia is the Australian Research Council and they take note of the NHMRC guidelines. The NHMRC also has a statement on human experimentation. Supplementary note 7 has been issued to that. It prohibits gene therapy that has the potential to change the genetic material that can be passed on from one generation to another. Human cloning is governed by state law. The Commonwealth does not have the right to legislate in this area. In Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria it is illegal. However, in the other states and territories what is not covered by the NHMRC or the Australian Research Council would almost certainly be found to be unethical through either hospital or other research institute guidelines. I can assure honourable members that the government is of the view that experimentation on human cloning is beyond the bounds of what are acceptable guidelines. The National Health and Medical Research Council is aware of our view. NA

Greenhouse Gas Emissions

Speaker: Ms JEANES
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does Australia support the EU proposals for a IS per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 201O? What steps is the government taking to ensure Australia's economic and environmental interests are protected in climate change negotiations?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Kingston for her question. I know she is very concerned about environmental issues and I know she is also concerned about jobs, including for the people of Kingston and the people of Adelaide and South Australia. The government has received advice of the European Union's negotiating target proposal for all OECD countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by 15 per cent compared to the 1990 levels by 2010. The EU intends to submit this proposal to the negotiations currently taking place in Bonn. The House may be aware that the Australian government is arguing for what is described as a differentiation proposal in these climate change negotiations. That is to ensure that there is an equitable sharing of the burden amongst all of the so-called annexe 1 countries, which are in effect the OECD countries. There is no reason why this country should be asked to bear a disproportionate burden in addressing the climate change issue. The European Union proposal contains a differentiation proposal itself. It contains differentiation for individual EU member states but excludes this possibility for the OECD countries. So there are different targets for individual member states-for example, Portugal's target allows emissions in 2010 to increase by 40 per cent, Greece's target is to increase by 30 per cent, Spain's by 17 per cent and so on. Australia, along with other non-EU OECD is being asked to accept a uniform flat rate reduction of 15 per cent, and that is clearly not going to be acceptable. It is inconsistent for the EU to deny others what they are using as a key element of their own efforts to address climate change. The fact is that a 15 per cent reduction target by 2010 is unrealistic. As we see it, it is little more than a negotiating tactic at this stage by the European Union. It also has to be said that the European Union proposal is frankly unworkable because it does not provide a sound framework for long-term cooperative action to address the climate change issue.

Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

This 1996- is the same minister who in 1993-although he was in opposition back then-proposed nuclear power facilities right across Australia. Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Nehl)Order! The level of conversation in the chamber is far too high. Please be courteous from the to the honourable gentleman.

Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course this minister, as the then opposition spokesman, was forced to withdraw this proposal in January 1994. In an interview of the day, he went on the record saying that he no longer felt this was an economically viable proposition. Indeed, he rejected the hypothetical proposition which he had been advancing for the electorate. He went on to say: And wethat is, the coalition partiesbelieve that nuclear enrichment and nuclear powered electricity are alien concepts to Australians and they're economically unfeasible. Indeed they are alien concepts, as is the concept of nuclear fuel enrichment plants in Australia. This minister has form in this area. This is an alien concept. It was an alien concept in 1994 and it is an alien concept in 1997. What are we referring to when we talk about nuclear fuel reprocessing? Most members are familiar with nuclear power plants. They are familiar with the very safe operation of the Lucas Heights facility over the last 40 years. But most people are not so familiar with nuclear fuel reprocessing. You have to wait some 30 years for the spent fuel rods to cool sufficiently for them to be reprocessed. They are then treated with concentrated nitric acid, forming a very hot liquid and some gaseous components as well. This hot, thermally active and radioactive liquid is then separated into its respective components. Those components are uranium and waste material which is still very radioactive and in liquid form, and there is the potential for a small amount of plutonium to come from this process as well. That plutonium is very significant, and I think honourable members should keep sight of that as we proceed through this discussion. One thing nuclear fuel reprocessing does not do is that it does not reduce the level of radioactivity of the material concerned. At the end ?f the pr-c.ess, you still have very substantIal quantItIes of radioactive material, although you have it in separate components. Instead of a mixture of nuclear fuel, you now have the uranium, the plutonium and the liquid waste separated out. You do not have any less radioactivity, but you do have a massive increase in the volume of this material. We are now required to deal with massive amounts of liquid radioactive waste, and this is what the minister proposes to locate at Lucas Heights in the middle of suburban Sydney. Minister, this is not a vision for science; this is more an illusion which is going to become a nightmare for the people of Sutherland Shire. In the past.' the reasons one might propose for reprocessmg have been threefold. First for the military there was obviously the purPose of extracting the plutonium. I think this is an issue which will come back to haunt this minister.
