Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This government has joined with the previous government in moving towards the Canberra Commission proposition which will ensure that Australia takes a very strong stand in this world against nuclear proliferation. That is one of the most serious objectives which the previous government had in dealing with the Canberra Commission and on the international stage. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) has picked this topic up and continued to proceed with Australia's favourable outlook in that regard. What will our friends in the Western world say when we are in possession of plutonium? How does that leave our non-proliferation treaty obligations when, as a result of the minister's reprocessing ambitions, we have significant quantities of plutonium? How will we deal with those quantities-something that we do not want to have to deal with? Secondly, there used to be economic reasons for reprocessing. It used to be necessary - o extract the uranium from the reprocessing m order to have uranium to feed back into the nuclear fuel cycle. Uranium, of course is now quite plentiful. Australia is not short of urani.um, if it wishes to supply its reactor, and th-t IS no longer a necessary objective. The third reason is that it does in some small way facilitate disposal because you have separate components with which to deal rather than a homogenous group. But taken in totality in 1997, this is not an adequate reason to proceed with the reprocessing of nuclear fuel in this country. .Natura-ly, if the minister was to proceed with a pilot level plant, it would be a very expensive proposition. Japan is proceeding with one at the moment which will come onstream some time after 2000. This is a pilot plant for reprocessing fast reactor fuel in Japan. It will cost them something of the order of $1.5 billion. It will be a six-storey building with a two-storey basement, and it is still just a pilot plant. So precisely what is proposed for the Lucas Heights region here? Something of the same order? I sincerely hope not. Nuclear reprocessing is an option in England. The British government has established a number of very major reprocessing facilities in Dounreay and Sellafield that have been in operation for some time. There is a very strong view in the nuclear industry that the only reason those plants are continued, maintained and indeed expanded is because Britain and France-its colleague country in this regard-have already made substantial investments in the nuclear fuel cycle, and they have significant plants which need to be maintained. That is why they are in that business. Other countries, like Germany, which has recently abandoned a proposal to get involved with reprocessing, and the United States, which does not reprocess fuel, have rightly moved away from this technology and towards storage. That ought to be Australia's option, not the option of reprocessing fuel for our very modest nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights on Australian soil. As an alternative to a pilot plant, the minister may have in mind-and given his past enthusiasm for the nuclear industryimporting waste from other countries. Indeed, he has commented on this as being part of the fast growing Asian nuclear region. He may want to attack some of his theories in the nuclear club by having Australia be part of this arrangement and import nuclear waste. 1 think the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) would need to ask what the hidden agenda is behind the government's plans for an airport at Holsworthy. Is one of those agendas the importation of nuclear fuel through that airport? I sincerely hope not, - cause that would expose us to even greater nsks than the minister's bizarre proposal already does. If you want to see exactly what this kind of reprocessing plant can leave you with after a few years of operation, you can do no worse that look at the United States. One of the main reasons they have now moved away from this technology-if you look at Hanford-is the massive amounts of liquid waste which they have had to deal with and the enormous environmental degradation which that has produced on that site. The United States now has a super-fund to clean up these kinds of areas. The cost of that is massive to the US economy; the damage to the local environment is enormous; and the technology is far from useful for that country, which is why they have moved away from it. Minister, you have some very hard decisions to make in this area. These decisions have come up on your watch. I know that is tough but that is the reality of politics. You wanted to get into government. Now you are in, you will have to take some of these hard decisions, make some of the hard plans and put in the work that is required to ensure Australia has some sound policies in the future. This reactor is now nearly 40 years old. It is not quite as old as he or I, but the reality is that I suspect the reactor is in not quite such good condition as either of us. The reality is that we need to plan for the future. Minister, instead of coming up with this kind of distracting proposal which focuses public attention on an entirely absurd proposal to reprocess waste at Lucas Heights, why don't you focus public attention instead on the real questions? Australia needs to address the issue of the future of the Lucas Heights reactor and the future of the Lucas Heights site, because the Nuclear Safety Bureau has very clearly said they will not continue to recertify this plant much beyond 2003. ANSTO itself says that it is essential we start making decisions at about now. The reality is that the minister should be putting the effort into determining the future of that site and not into proposing strange new ways of getting ANSTO into the world nuclear club. That is a technology looking for a solution, instead of a reasoned plan for the future of Australia's nuclear industry focused on that research reactor. This is where you need some serious vision. We do have an issue about the storage of the fuel rods from Lucas Heights. They continue to mount up. Governments for the last 38 years have known that they would, and the reality is that that has to be dealt as and when the problem arises. We have now reached a point where that needs further serious consideration. The previous government sent one shipload back for reprocessing, and that will return to Australia in some 25 to 30 years in reprocessed form. The significance is that that site is now reaching a point where in the next two or three years, or sooner, you will need some serious answers to those questions. Not only will you have to look at the issue of the future of the plant, but also whether Australia needs another research reactor and, if it does, whether that should be at Lucas Heights or at some alternative site. Those are the kinds of questions to which the people of Australia, particularly the people of Sutherland Shire, are demanding answers to. They are not looking for new ways of getting us further and deeper into the nuclear cycle or of creating further and deeper environmental problems in that region. They are looking, instead, for long-term answers and serious work to be done on this topic. You must also face the reality that Synroc has had substantial investment in it over the years. I understand that. But if we are going to use a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights merely as a demonstration technique for Synroc, then I think that is a very wasteful extravagance in terms of federal funding. It is a very dangerous proposition for the people of that area and it is not a suitable way to ensure the continuation of that technology. Normally, I would be the first to join with the minister in support of Australian industry and Australian science through the commitment of government resources. It is unfortunate that his government has not displayed the same commitment to industry when it reduced the research and development grants, when it abolished syndication, when it pulled back funding from ANSTO, AIMS and CSIRO and when it has sought to wipe out industry policy in general, as well as some of that scientific collaboration in research. Normally, I would come out and support the minister if he was proposing to invest federal funds in the development of a technology. But this is not the way to further the with development of the Synroc technology. You cannot use the people of Sutherland Shire and Lucas Heights as pawns in a game which is merely for the development of a technology. I support the furtherance of that technology, if it is possible. We have a long-term investment in it-governments of both political colours have that. It deserves a degree of bipartisan support, as does ANSTO in its general activities. That is something you have always had and will have from us on this side of the House. But this is not the kind of proposal which is deserving of bipartisan support. This moves right outside of that area when it puts the citizens of that district at risk. ANSTO have a very strong record of safety. They have a first-class record of research in the past, and it is very contemptuous of them to put their reputation at risk by this kind of proposal. You do them a great disservice by injuring their public reputation and their position of public trust and confidence in this way. There was no need to involve them in this kind of proposition. It is not a solution you need to propose in order to deal with the nuclear fuel rods from Lucas Heights. Most governments in the world are coming to the conclusion that dry storage is the way to go in the medium-term future for these kinds of fuel rods. There is no reason why that could not continue in the way that it has. Indeed, the Senate last year, in an all-party report, recommended this kind of method of storage for Australia. It certainly did not recommend-and I am sure that its members would disagree with you now-the reprocessing option for Lucas Heights. This is not a good new industry for Australia, Minister. Focus your attention on the good science which is coming out of Australian industry, on the good science which is coming out of our national science agencies like CSIRO, ANSTO, AIMS and the universities. Do not expose them to this kind of nuclear 'cowboyry'. Certainly, do not put the people of Hughes and Sutherland Shire at risk through the environmental degradation which this proposal would implement. Guarantee them today that you will not proceed with this. For the sake of those people, for the sake of those families and for the sake of the future of that area, give the guarantee which for the. last two weeks you have failed and refused to give in this House and outside of this House. Give them the assurance which they and we seek from you today-that you will abandon this absurd proposal for a reprocessing facility at Lucas Heights in Sydney now.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) must have woken up this morning, seen that Sydney Morning Herald front page story and thought all of his Christmases had come at once. That story had nothing new to reveal, no extra information and no interpretation beyond what I have been saying for several weeks and what most other news organisations in this country have been reporting for several weeks. Let us deal with that first and foremost. There is nothing new in the story in the Sydney Morning Herald. It correctly reports that the government is examining the options available to it for the disposal of the 1,600 spent fuel rods at Lucas Heights. I have been grievously misrepresented by the member when he concluded in his address-leaving aside a number of misrepresentations during his address-by saying that we have decided on a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights. That is completely wrong. Despite the member for Bonython understandably rejoicing in the event of today and in the attention that it has brought him and the issue, he has three major problems-and he did not overcome any of the problems during his address. The first is that the Party did nothing in government for 13 years to address this problem. We have inherited this. We have come to government, and the advice from ANSTO is that next year the storage facilities at Lucas Heights will be exhausted. The spent fuel rods have to be dealt with. They have to be reprocessed. So you have no credibility. This is opportunism of the worse kind. It is politics at its most base. Instead of seeking a reasoned, sensible and calm debate on this issue, the Labor Party seizes on a front page story dramatically presented with a headline, photos and sketches but which reveals nothing new or different. They come in here and turn up the temperature. During his whole address, the member threw around words like 'nuclear power', 'nuclear fuel enrichment' and 'nuclear proliferation', instead of addressing the one issue-that is, how do we dispose of the spent fuel which is an unavoidable by-product of the research reactor? The second problem is that the Labor Party spent, in round figures, $40 million in research into Synroc technology. If I understand them correctly, we are now not entitled to consider that as an option. You tell the Australian taxpayers, firstly, that you spent $40 million over 13 years on a technology that you were never going to use in governmentand which never sees the funding, by the way-and, secondly, that we are not entitled to consider it as an option. You tell them that you have wasted $40 million. You will not. Of course we are entitled to consider the Synroc technologies. You would have done in government, I suspect. But from your remarks now, I am not so certain. What has happened to the $40 million? It has just been wasted? It has been worthless technology? Of course we have to consider it. Thirdly, you have no policy yourself on how to dispose of these 1,600 spent fuel rods. I listened very carefully to every word, particularly to see whether or not you would finish up with a declaration of how you would dispose of the 1,600 spent fuel rods. The member for Bonython failed to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. So what credibility do you Labor have? With what seriousness should we regard your protestations on behalf of the people of Hughes, for whom we have real interest because we want to dispose of the spent fuel rods? It is a ludicrous MPI and, quite frankly, a waste of this parliament's time. The government has said that we can send the spent fuel rods back to the United Kingdom for reprocessing. Do you want that? Should they go back to Dounreay, Scotland? No answer. They can go back to the United States for reprocessing. Do you want that? Should they go back to the United States? No answer. Or we can process them domestically. We will consider them, looking at all of the environment, social and economic considerations. How do we deal with an opposition that can inflame what can be, at times, a sensitive community issue if people in responsible positions do not handle it properly, yet still fail to tell us what they would do with the problem they gave us after total inaction over 13 years? Do not take my word for it. You have been quoting the Sydney Morning Herald. I refer you again, as I did in question time, to a report by Leigh Dayton on 22 August 1994. Did she cane the then Labor government! She said: Australia's policy on the disposal of radioactive waste is definitely not a shambles. Far worse-it doesn't even exit. The article goes through your cowardly inaction on this issue. Even though it was drawn to your attention in the media in August 1994, the Labor Party did nothing until it lost government in March 1996. Twenty months later you still had done nothing. The shadow minister puts up this idea that we can leave them there. Correct me if I am wrong, please take a personal explanation, but to the best of my understanding, you said, 'Leave them in dry storage.' But they are corroding. We cannot leave them indefinitely. That is the opposition we have to deal with. How do we take you seriously? You have no credibility, you put up no alternative and the storage is exhausted in 1998. The government does have to take a decision. You were gracious enough to say there are hard decisions; you were not so gracious as to give us any indication of what those decisions should be. So you are scaremongering. I expect it from the extremist groups and the Democrats on these types of issues most of the time, but not from the Labor Party opposition. I would have expected a lot more. You can exaggerate, you can hype up and terrify people if you really want to on this issue. The fact is that you have a responsibility, particularly as much of this problem is of your making, to assist the government to solve it, or else, if not supporting the final decision that we make, to put up your own alternative. Until then, quite frankly, I-and I do not see how anyone in the community would-cannot take you seriously. You had the gall to lecture me about the need to respect and support ANSTO. The member for Bonython should know that the government has a very strong commitment to ANSTO. We recognise that the spent fuel represents an unavoidable by-product of the HIFAR research reactor which is used to produce almost all of Australia's nuclear medicines. Some 260,000 Australians benefit from the radioisotopes every year. As a major national scientific facility, the reactor also plays an important part in education and research outside of ANSTO with 7,000 hours of research time provided to universities in both Australia and New Zealand on an annual basis. It is one of the world's largest sources of irradiated silicon used in advanced computer chip production. HIFAR is also used to analyse more than 33,000 samples each year for the minerals and oil exploration industries in Australia. The government is very supportive of this essential facility. In medical, environmental, industrial and research terms, ANSTO serves the nation extremely well. It does not deserve the adverse publicity which the opposition and the minor parties are now visiting upon it. The hypocrisy of anyone, including the member for Bonython, to accuse me or the government of letting down ANSTO is astounding. It is they, the opposition, who are stirring up community feelings on this issue. We will fully, properly and responsibly consider all of the factors that go to make up the different options available to the government for this unavoidable problem. It is not going to go away. Nobody at ANSTO is going to be fooled by this phoney, mealy-mouthed defence on their part. It is the member for Bonython who should be ashamed and embarrassed to show his face anywhere near the Lucas Heights site. We have full support for ANSTO and what it does. It plays a crucial role in Australia for both health and manufacturing terms. So many thousands of Australians owe their lives to the research carried out at ANSTO. Remember that ANSTO is Australia's only producer of radioisotopes which are used in treating and detecting illnesses which include cancer, thyroid disease, heart disease and others. There are over 100 nuclear medicine departments in Australia performing an estimated 300,000 diagnostic tests and 4,000 treatments annually with a combined value approaching $200 million. In an average year, more than 250,000 Australians-I mentioned 260,000 Australians earlier on-will have a nuclear medicine procedure and, on average, one in every two Australians can now expect one in their lifetime. These and other non-invasive procedures have replaced the need for much exploratory surgery to assess a patient's condition, signifithe cantly reducing discomfort and cost to patients. Use of these tests also reduces the length of hospital stays. Sales of ANSTO's radio pharmaceuticals to the Australian market now exceed $11 million annually. Some $700,000 of ANSTO's radio pharmaceuticals are also exported to South-East Asia, where the market is estimated to be $25 million and growing at more than 10 per cent annually. Mr Martyn Evans-No-one is opposing that.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: No-one is opposing it, the member for Bonython interjects, yet he will not tell us what his party or the government would or should do in regard to the spent fuel. What should you do? Mr Martyn Evans-That's why you're the minister.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That is why you ignored it for 13 years. The reply is, That's why you're the minister.' We most certainly will be making a decision. We are not going to avoid our responsibility for 13 years, like you did, but oppositions still have to have policies. You are out there scaring the community. You are out there inflaming community fears. You tell them what you would do. Mr Leo MCLeay-You've frightened the wits out of them.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Watson is not in his place, and will keep quiet.

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Bonython is policy-free on all the issues. He has the temerity to sit there and say, 'It's your decision.' Of course it is our decision. We will make it. That is why I have always been open and honest and set out the options available to the government. Now we want to know what his policy is, especially how the opposition are going to tell Australian taxpayers that they have spent $40 million over 13 years and the Synroc technology is going to be junked. For any opposition frontbencher to taunt the government by saying, 'You're the government, you're the minister, that's what you get paid for, make decision,' and not have any alternative is hypocritical and cowardly. We will make the decision-make no mistake about that. Events will be forced on us. The storage facilities are exhausted next year, so we will make the decision in the next few months. But you tell us what your policy is. We have to go into all of the detail, make all of the calculations and take into account so many different factors. I am not asking that of you; I am just asking for a one-line policy from you. I will not require you to prepare a Fightback of 600 pages, with all of the supporting documentation, but you just tell us what your bottom line is. What is the member for Bonython's one-sentence destination for the 1,600 spent fuel rods? Until then, you have no place in this debate and you ought to be condemned for the way you are stirring it up for your own purposes. ANSTO of course uses the radioisotopes in a variety of ways to boost productivity, from checking gas and oil pipelines to the development of newer high-tech materials. In the environmental field, by using radioisotopes, we can trace sewage from ocean outfalls or small leaks from complex systems, such as power stations and heat exchanges. HIFAR is used, as I say, to analyse more than 33,000 samples each year for the minerals and oil exploration industries in Australia. So it is a major scientific facility. It plays a very important part in education and research out of ANSTO. For all these reasons, the government will support the institution. We will solve the problem that we have inherited from Labor and, notwithstanding some of the worse kinds of opportunist politics imaginable by the opposition, we will win the confidence of the local and, indeed, the more widespread community. (Extension of time granted) I will not need long, but I just want to reinforce a couple of points. What did the Labor Party do over 13 years? What were their decisions? None. Instead, it seems that they put their head in the sand and thought the spent fuel rods would go away naturally. The Labor Party refused to make any decision regarding the spent fuel rods. Worse still, they continued to fund, at the rate of millions of dollars a year, the Synroc technology, seemingly-from what the shadow minister now tells us-without any intention of ever using it, without any intention of capitalising on that research which extended from 1980, but most of the money was spent during Labor's 13 years. Even now, they will not tell us what their policy is. On all those grounds, the Labor Party and the shadow minister are revealed for what they really are. They are just cheap political opportunists who stand condemned for the way they are stirring up local feeling with total disregard to people's natural feelings on this issue. The way they throw around the nuclear spectre, next we will be hearing from the shadow minister the imagery of Chernobyl or Three Mile Island. This, instead, is one of the options available to the government, which is reasonably and responsibly considering them before reaching a final decision. For those members who have just come in, let me remind them of a priceless, memorable interjection, never to be forgotten, by the member for Bonython. When I asked him whether he would send the spent fuel rods to Dounreay in the United Kingdom for reprocessing I received no answer. When I asked him whether he would send them to the United States for reprocessing I received no answer. When I asked him whether he would reprocess them domestically I received no answer. His only reply was, 'You're the government, you're the minister, you make the decision.' We will make the decision-a decision they avoided studiously at great expense to Australians for 13 years. But you tell us what your policy is. Just tell us in one sentence the destination: United Kingdom, United States or Australia. That is all you have to tell us. Until then, you have no credibility and, until then, you are revealed for the political opportunist you really are.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Barton) (3.51 p.m.)One may well ask what this government is doing to my friend the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale). First, they are giving her an airport. Now they are throwing in a nuclear reprocessing plant. When are they going to throw in a quarantine station or a hospital for contagious diseases, just to take another 20 per cent off the property values of residents in her electorate? The development of such a reprocessing plant is going to have a dramatic effect on not only the residents of Sutherland but also all those in the surrounding areas, including my electorate of Barton and the surrounding electorates of Banks, Watson, Throsby and Werriwa because they would be the routes that all this nuclear material would be shipped and transported through in order to get to Lucas Heights. It is an issue that very much affects that entire region of Sydney. Indeed, the issue affects Australia. The minister has asked, 'Why have you spent all this money on developing the Synroc technology?' The fact of the matter is that that technology is extremely valuable and is to be used overseas in other reprocessing plants that already exist. But because that investment is being made in that technology, you do not have to dive headlong into the water-indeed, contaminated water--of developing your own nuclear facility at the grubby, literally poisonous end of the nuclear cycle. The minister said that we were being emotive when we used terms such as 'nuclear power' and 'nuclear fuel'. I do not know what the subject matter of the debate is if it is not about the by-products of nuclear power and nuclear fuel. Let us talk about radioactive contamination and the effects of radiation as indicated in No time to waste, a report of April 1996. It says: The long teml health effects of radiation exposure are manifested by mutation of cells, increased aging capacity of the body, and increased incidence of leukemia, birth defects and cancer. The government asks, 'What are we going to do?' What they are doing is pre-empting research and investigation which was under way during the period of the Labor government. One was an investigation into the future of Lucas Heights-my strong view is that it should have no future; it is right now smack bang in a very beautiful residential area-and the second was to identify a site for the future disposal of waste, including an investigation into the characteristics of that site. This government is proposing to dive headlong into the contaminated pool of this reprocessing plant without first of all investitine gating those issues. In other words, they trying to inject life into the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights by giving it another purpose rather than investigating whether its current purpose should be continued-a very live and sensitive issue in the entire region. The minister-with respect, he has fallen victim to the Yes, Minister men; perhaps with experience he will be able to detect where they are coming from-has said that the Sydney Morning Herald is only reporting what he has been saying for the last few weeks. Today's Sydney Morning Herald Officials envisage using Australia's experimental "Synroc" technology for immobilising nuclear waste, thereby demonstrating its first commercial use to the burgeoning nuclear power industry in the Asia-Pacific region. After reprocessing, the waste would be buried somewhere in Outback Australia. If that is not saying that the conduit to outback Australia is coming through a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights, I do not know what is. They are diving into the Asia-Pacific nuclear processing technology area without Australians deciding whether it is an industry that they want at all. I think that if there were a referendum, Australians would say, 'Stay right out of this one,' just as Europe, Germany and the United States are doing. Without a mandate whatsoever, they are diving straight into this technology-a commercial enterprise for the whole Asia-Pacific regionwhich collects all their waste and reprocesses it. That waste is going to come in from ships and presumably it will come in through Port Botany, through my electorate and through surrounding electorates. Even if it is not going to bring in supplies from overseas, a reprocessing plant most certainly is going to collect waste from areas all around Australia, such as hospitals and irradiation plants that we used to use for irradiating carpets and food and so forth. In mass quantities, to one big bulk store, it will be coming through all the electorates in that area of Sydney. The government has already demonstrated that it is not prepared to consult with local residents. In March of last year there was the disgraceful incident when the government shipped out spent fuel rods to Dounreay through my electorate of Barton in a clandesoperation between midnight and 2 a.m. are without telling people in the electorates. Recently, a British ship was carrying Japanese nuclear waste around our shores and the government did not tell the Australian public that that was occurring. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) is reported as saying that it was a security risk for the route to be public knowledge because of the potential for terrorism to sink the ship. That is precisely the response I got from ANSTO to the March shipment issue. ANSTO considers itself above the law because its nuclear said: science is so sensitive. But in the meantime the residents of all our electorates have to bend over and cop it. They do not have any input whatsoever into what is happening. It is a circumstance where there has been no identification of accountability and no assumption of risk. For instance, who was responsible in that Dounreay shipmentwas it ANSTO, the truck driver or the police who were supervising in case of an accident or some terrorist attack? Who would the residents have sued if it had occurred? I point out to the government that you cannot buy insurance for a nuclear disaster. Mercantile Mutual, for example, says that loss, damage or liability as a result of the use, existence or escape of nuclear weapons material or ionising radiation from, or contamination by radioactivity from, :my nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from the combustion of nuclear fuel is excluded from their policy. Homes and residents in all our areas are not insured against damage from nuclear material and trucks are going to be coming past them day and night. In the April 1996 report of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, entitled No Time To Waste, there is this comment about the compliance with the transport code in respect of the transportation of waste: ... the [Transport] Code requirements are often followed simply because of the unavailability of appropriate transport containers, or the lack of understanding of the Code or both. With the code unworkable, nuclear fuel from all over Australia coming through our electorates into Lucas Heights and ANSTO exempted from state law, our residents are again supposed to cop it. Their kids are sleeping at night, and they do not know if there is a truck carrying contaminated material is going past their front yards. That is an outrageous and unnecessary situation. The minister did not have to go anywhere near this area. He could have left it at examining what is going to happen with Lucas Heights and the feasibility of other sites for the disposal of waste. Instead, he has preempted all the inquiries that were taking place, saying: 'Let us dive into this new economic opportunity' - that is, contaminating Australia. The government is to be condemned for causing the fear that it has. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I looked at this MPI proposal and thought: 'This is most extraordinary.' It talks about the consequences of a proposal. If any of the honourable members opposite had bothered to listen to the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr MCGauran) at question time, they would have realised what a terrible MPI this was and withdrawn it on the spot. The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) has made a complete fool of himself, and so has his mate the member for Barton (Mr MCClelland), who had to follow on after having heard the minister make it very clear in his answer to a question at question time that the government has not made any decision. It could not be any clearer than that. I feel sorry for the poor members of the Labor Party who have had to get up and put this MPI. Obviously, the Labor Party were desperate to find something to put up here. They thought about the poor old member for Bonython and thought: 'He hasn't really had much', and he put this one up because he could not think of much else. It is very sad. But it reflects the judgment that the Australnot Ian people made just over 12 months ago when they put the Labor Party over there because they realised that they were no longer fit for government. That is doubly or trebly true of the former member for Hughes-I will come back to that, because that really was the consequence of what had happened. Thank God, he is no longer here, because of some of the damage he did. If you want to look at what can be damaging for the Australian community and for the people of Hughes in particular, have a look at what the former member was trying to do to this country. Not only is this a sadly misguided MPI but it is also-because of the way the arguments have been presented to the chamber todayone of the most irresponsible in a long time. It is most unfortunate. It does nothing for the credibility of the opposition and very little for the credibility of this chamber to have people coming in here and making such utterly irresponsible and misleading statements. Mrs Bailey-Scaremongering.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is scaremongering, as my good friend and colleague over there says. The opposition are clearly desperate to find something to put to this chamber and have come up with this. What is even worse is that, with these utterly misleading statements, they have been playing on the fears of good, decent, ordinary people in Sydney and they have been insulting people, trying to assume that they are ignorant of what all this stands for and of all the fine things that ANSTO has done. My good colleague the member for Gippsland and minister for science has already outlined what a fantastic job ANSTO has done. I might add they were doing that while the Labor Party was in power, too. I did not hear the Labor Party complaining at the time about all the good things that were done by ANSTO for the health of Australians. The way the Labor Party has behaved is quite extraordinary, and I would be far more concerned for the people of Australia and for the people Hughes about having a recycled member for Hughes in the form of Mr Tickner. Look at the damaging consequences of what he did. Look at the Hindmarsh Island fiasco and think. what a reincarnation of the Keating government would mean. We would have the former member for Hughes back. It would be a disaster. The budget deficit would come back. Interest rates would go up. We would see all the woes that the people of Australia thought they had got rid of when, in March last year, they decided that they had to get rid not only of the then member for Hughes but also--Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This debate is about the nuclear reprocessing plant the government wants to put in the electorate of Hughes. It not about interest rates or anything like that, although house prices may go down if this gets built.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Jenkins)The honourable member for Wannon will address the matter of the discussion of the matter of public importance.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I reiterate: if we look at the terms of the matter for public importance, we realise that it is a complete furphy-as the minister pointed out-so we have to talk about other things related to this motion: that is, the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) and the former member for Hughes. The minister, in his complete demolition of this matter, made some very salient points about the Labor Party's problems. He made three points very clearly and enunciated them in a way that all honourable members opposite should have listened to. Firstly and most importantly, he pointed out that Labor had 13 years to look at the problem of what to do with the nuclear fuel rods, and they did nothing-except spend $40 million thinking about what they might do. They never actually did anything. That is the first point, and all honourable members opposite ought to be reminded of that, particularly those who were not here during the debate earlier. The second point he made clearly was that the $40 million was spent on developing Synroc. Then the member for Bonython said, 'That's okay, but we are not allowed to use it in Australia.' We will develop it, but that is for someone else-not in my backyard. It has got to be in another country. We do not care where, as long as it is not in Australia. The opposition, having failed to learn from 13 years in government, has. no policy today. There was absolutely nothing put forward in the debate today to tell us what we might do. So all we get is this scaremongering and, frankly, I think it is damned irresponsible the way the Labor Party put all this up. It ought to be made very clear to those people who live in Sydney that the Labor Party have done nothing but go out and try to run a scaremongering campaign-and insult is people's intelligence by making all sorts of outrageous claims. I would have thought the way the member for Barton approached thisMr Leo MCLeay-My point of order is on standing order 85, which provides: . .. a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his or her own arguments, or of the arguments used by other Members in debatethe chairmay direct the Member to discontinue his or her speech. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if the member for Wannon continues to rehearse what he has said and what the minister has said you might draw his attention to standing order 85.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! The honourable member for Wannon will continue.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your support. As I was saying, the presentation by the member for Barton was one of the most irresponsible we have heard in this place for a long time. He got up and made a very misleading speech, full of half-truths, when he said, 'Well, there might be the introduction of a quarantine station; there might be a hospital for infectious es.' Then he said, 'Synroc has to go overseas'-the same sort of thing. Then he started on the problems of radiation. He even referred to some place called 'Nuclear Heights' - I do not know where it is. He was getting carried away with what he was putting forward. Then we got onto terrorists, trying to bring in all the fearmongering he possibly could, not once having listened to what the minister had said in the answer to his question in the first place. I really think the Labor Party come to this debate in a very poor way. They put forward a proposition today that does not even stand up. The smartest thing they could have done was withdraw it before it even got listed for debate. Having listened to what the minister had already said, it was quite clear they had made a dreadful mistake; and now they are coming along, still trying to create fear. Having already been made to look like fools over this whole thing, they then turned around trying to run this fearmongering and deceptive sort of debate, trying to create fear amongst all those people who live in Sydney and totally misleading them. 1 suggest that this is a very poor effort and the chamber deserves better than they have heard today.

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: SENATE
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This dairy produce levy bill has two purposes. Firstly, this bill, in conjunction with the Australian Animal Health Council (Live-Stock Industries) Funding Amendment Bill 1997, will establish a statutory levy to fund the dairy industry's contribution to the Australian paid Animal Health Council Ltd. Secondly, this bill will double the maximum research levy rate specified in the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986. The Australian Animal Health Council Ltd, Council. or AAHC for short, has been established as Australia's peak animal health body. Its mission is to ensure that Australia's animal health service system is capable of maintainin ing acceptable national animal health standfor ards which meet both consumer needs and market requirements in domestic and internavalue tional markets. AAHC is jointly owned and funded by the Commonwealth, state governments, the Northern Territory government and the peak representative bodies of Australia's livestock industries, including the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. To date, the dairy industry's contribution to AAHC has been met from surplus moneys paid to the Dairy Research and Development Corporation upon cessation of the exotic animal disease program adjourned. and supplemented by a payment from the Australian Dairy Corporation. The peak industry body, the Australian Dairy Industry Council, has sought the establishment of a levy mechanism as a transparent means of meeting the industry's funding commitment to the AAHC, as currently Primary occurs with Australia's other livestock indusmove: tries. The levy would be imposed in the same manner as other dairy industry levies, that is, on the milk fat and protein content of an individual producer's milk supply. The need to increase the maximum research levy rate has arisen because the current operational research levy rate, which partially funds the activities of the Dairy Research and Development Corporation, is very close to the legislated maximum rate. The present situation provides very little scope for further increases and may significantly curtail the ability of the Dairy Research and Development Corporation to respond to the needs of the industry in the near future. I would point out that a doubling of the maximum research levy will not automatically lead to a rise in the actual research levy rate by producers. Rather, it will provide scope for the dairy industry to seek government approval for an increase in the actual levy rate, as the need arises. The increase in the maximum research levy rate has the full support of the Australian Dairy Industry The dairy industry has enjoyed significant growth in recent years, with milk production 1996-97 expected to pass nine billion litres the first time on record. Around half of this production will be exported with the of exports expected to be about $1.8 billion. These amendments will enhance the capacity of the dairy industry to undertake animal health and research and development activities which, in tum, will contribute to further industry growth and improved competitiveness in domestic and international markets. I commend the bill to honourable members and hand over the explanatory memoranda. Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) NA COUNCIL (LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRIES) FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned. NA (No.1) 1997  Small Business and Consumer Affairs) (4.19 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Tariff Act) to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content. Under item 2 of the schedule to the Tariff Act, 'spirituous beverages' are subject to duties of excise, which are calculated at a dollar amount per litre of alcohol in each beverage. The term was introduced into the Tariff Act in 1985 with the intention of making excisable any beverage that contained a spirit. Since that time, all such beverages have been treated as excisable regardless of their alcohol content, including beverages whose alcohol content ranges from five per cent to nine per cent, for example, the rum and cola mixer drinks. In November 1994 Carlton and United Breweries, CUB, commenced the manufacture of the product known as 'Subzero Alcoholic Soda' which had an alcohol content of approximately 5.5 per cent. The Australian Customs Service, the ACS, considered 'Subzero' excisable under subitem 2(H) of the schedule to the Tariff Act as a spirituous beverage. CUB appealed the decision of the ACS to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the AAT. On 7 June 1996 the AAT determined that the production of 'Subzero', with such a low alcohol content by volume, could not be described as spirituous and was therefore not excisable under subitem 2(H). The decision was based on what the AA T considered is commonly regarded as the definition of 'spirit' in the community, which is a strong alcoholic liquor usually containing not less than 37 per cent alcohol by volume. The ACS is appealing this decision to the Federal Court. Since the AAT decision, CUB has ceased manufacturing 'Subzero' using alcohol derived by distillation. However, there are several other companies-UDA, Remy Australia, Swift and Moore and Angove-who manufacture beverages of low alcohol content which are based on, for example, brandy or whisky. The ACS has continued to impose excise duty under subitem 2(H) on these beverages as they are considered by the ACS to be spirituous beverages. The payments of excise duty by these other manufacturers are being made under deposit in accordance with section 154 of the Excise Act 1901 on the basis that, since the AA T 'Subzero' decision, these manufacturers allege that these beverages are no longer excisable. Prior to this decision, there was no dispute with manufacturers of the low alcohol beverages using distilled alcohol as to their excisability nor to their proper classification to subitem 2(H) of the schedule to the Tariff Act. In order to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, it is proposed to amend the Tariff Act to: (i) delete all references to 'spirituous beverages' in the schedule and item 2 (item 1 of schedule 1 refers); and (ii) clarify that excise liability is imposed upon all beverages which contain distilled alcohol (new subitem 2(H), item 2 of schedule 1 refers). The combination of these amendments will remove any connotation as to the strength that an alcoholic beverage must be before it will be excisable. All such beverages will continue to be excisable regardless of their alcohol content and the excise duty will be calculated according to the alcohol content of the beverages. It is also proposed that the amendments will take effect on and from 3 February 1996. The effect of the retrospective commencement date of the amendments will be to extinguish all rights of appeal to the AAT in relation to the excisability of low alcohol beverages and all rights to refunds of excise duty in respect of such beverages. The commencement of the amendments on this date is considered justifiable on the following grounds: (a) As previously referred to, the intention of the term 'spirituous beverages' was to make excisable any beverage that contained a spirit and there had never been any dispute as to this intention prior to the 'Subzero' case. It is considered that the amendments are not altering the law with respect to alcoholic beverages as it stood at the time of the 'Subzero' decision but are merely clarifying what was the status quo. It is therefore considered appropriate that the amendments commence on 3 February 1996 to remove the technical loophole which was uncovered in the Tariff Act by that decision which this amending legislation is now removing. (b) The commencement of the amendments on 3 February 1996 would not require the retrospective recovery of any excise duty from the manufacturers of the alcoholic beverages. The excise duty has continued to be paid by the manufacturers, under deposit, and the 3 February 1996 commencement would protect the government against all claims for recovery of this duty. If the amendments do not commence on 3 February 1996, however, the government might be liable to pay $12.6 million in refunds of excise duty if the Federal Court confirms the AAT decision in favour of CUB. Given that the products manufactured by these companies have been sold duty paid, such a favourable decision to the companies would represent a windfall gain to them, with little chance that it would be returned to the consumers of the product. The proposed amendments, including their financial impact, are outlined in greater detail in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: OVERSEAS STUDENTS
text: Warringah-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (4.26 p.m.)-I move: That the requested amendment be made. This legislation is an important part of quality assurance in a very important developing Australian industry. Our export education industry is now, on some measures, bigger than the wheat industry. It is a $1.9 billion a year industry. It attracts over 50,000 students every year to our country. As one distinguished academic said to me graphically but inelegantly the other day, 'Every overseas student on our campus is $100,000 on the hoof for Australia.' Mr Latham interjecting

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: OVERSEAS STUDENTS
text: It was graphic and descriptive. This legislation is an important part of the quality assurance process. It is a continuation of the scheme that was introduced by the former government as a result of the unfortunate fact that 15,000 or so overseas students had to be bailed out by the taxpayers after their ELICOS colleges had gone under. The original legislation counted every student equally for the purposes of the registration charge. This amendment specifies that students doing courses 26 weeks or less will only count for half that value for the purposes of the registration charges. It acknowledges the large number of students doing short courses. I suppose the amendment means that the scheme can be rendered analogous to the purchase of motor car insurance: we are not only providing a discount for fleet buyers but also, in a sense, providing a discount for low mileage. The problem with the original piece of legislation was brought to the attention of the government by the industry associations, by the opposition, by the Australian Democrats and by the Greens. As a result, this amendment has gone through the Senate and it has now come before the House. May I say that the process by which this was achieved in the Senate is an example of how a responsible upper house can improve legislation. I commend the amendment to the House.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: OVERSEAS STUDENTS
text: On behalf of the opposition I wish to say that we are pleased that this amendment has been made. We are not very happy with the general process which was put into place about overseas students, but this does recognise a very important distinction and makes the burden much easier to bear for those students, of which there are very many, who are coming in for short courses. It is a very positive sign that the government has recognised that this amendment was needed and is going to assist in further ing the participation of overseas students in Australia. This is obviously a very important area and, indeed, a very important industry. We commend the amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative. text: As I foreshadowed in the second reading debate, boostthe Labor Party is opposed to the moving forward of a limitation on special depreciation on trading ships from the year 2002 to 1997. The shadow minister for transport indicated last year that the Labor Party was opposed to the way in which this government was attempting to put Australian shipowners at a disadvantage and attempting to encourage the entry of flags of inconvenience to Australia. There were measures debated in the parliament and the public arena through the course of 1996 that dealt with those matters. Speaker: Mr TANNER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Melbourne) (4.35 p.m.)Further to the comments of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), I would just like to add with respect to the abolition of the accelerated depreciation provisions regarding Australian ships that this is part of a broader attack on Australia's maritime industry by this government and it is particularly inappropriate when you consider the availability of accelerated depreciation for a range of other equipment, particularly in the agricultural and mining sectors. There are two key points that I would like to make in this debate on this issue. The first is that, almost without exception, the countries that Australia competes with in the maritime industry support their industries in some form or other with provisions such as accelerated depreciation, tax rebates for their seafarers and other initiatives. This is widespread throughout the world. It is not a level playing field. The situation in this industry is that virtually all of the players substantially subsidise their shipping industries. Australia has little hope of being able to be a significant player in the maritime industry without such supports. The former government put these supports in place, and not at huge cost-significant contributions but not at enormous cost to the budget-and without those supports the Australian shipping industry is likely to dwindle fairly rapidly into virtually nothing. It is something that suits ideological orientation of this government, which essentially sees transport as nothing more than a cost, that it is a cost to miners and farmers and that it is not an industry of importance in its own right. Yet; in areas like aviation and the maritime industry, transport delivers substantial export dollars, improves our balance of payments situation and, of course, provides skilled and well-paid jobs for Australians. If this provision is passed by this parliament, it will ensure the further export of Australian jobs and the further incursion of flags of convenience shipping into Australia with all of the threats that that imposes, particularly to our marine environment, and it will ensure that we have a reduction in our overall trading situation. Australia is the fifth biggest maritime nation on earth. In terms of volume carried per kilometre, Australia is the fifth largest market for shipping in the world. A situation where something like 97 per cent of that market is filled by foreign shipping is something that I do not think should be allowed to continue, yet this government clearly wants to see it at 100 per cent. The second point that I would make with respect to this provision is that, when you actually look at the various accelerated depreciation provisions that are available in other sectors, the hypocrisy of the government's position becomes very apparent. When you look at things like bulldozers, cropdusters, tractors, a whole range of agricultural equipment-and I am sure the Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan) knows this only too well because of his background-you see that accelerated depreciation of 20 per cent, which is what the former shipping provision was, up to as high as 40 per cent for things like cropdusters is almost universal across a wide range of high cost major capital equipment in agricultural and pastoral industries. One of the things this proposal exposes is that this government does not mind subsidies and does not mind a bit of assistance here and there provided it is to their mates. When it is the for industries that they do not approve of, when it is for industries that they are ideologically opposed to, they then say, 'No, you cannot have any assistance,' even when there is a strong case for it because of the nature of the international marketplace where there is widespread assistance amongst our competitors. This is a very stark contrast: a government that is prepared to have accelerated depreciation for the industries where it draws a lot of its political support from but for those where it does not see itself as politically favouredeven though they are just as important to Australia's overall economic position-it says, 'No, we will get rid of that support. We do not want to have anything to do with it.' The Australian community, the Australian maritime industry, the Australian shipbuilding industry and the various industries associated with the provision of maritime services will be the losers. It will not just be the Maritime Union of Australia and the seafarers, which the government hates. It will not just be those people and their jobs that are affected. There will be a range of flow-on effects as a result of the attacks on the maritime industry, of which this abolition of accelerated depreciation is but one part. Those flow-on effects will spread right through a variety of industries and a variety of economic opportunities and will ultimately have a negative impact on our balance of payments.

Title: NOES
text: I have one brief observation on schedule 3 which is probably appropriate for me to make now. It is of a general nature and I touched on it in my speech on the second reading. Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: NOES
text: As I outlined in the second reading debate, the Labor Party is opposed to this particular provision. We see no sense or rationale for reducing the invitation threshold for employee share schemes from 75 per cent to 66 per cent. This might be seen as a change of a NOES small proportion, but it is still a significant proportion. To move to a situation where, hypothetically, one-third of employees could be excluded from the share offer is, I believe, a step in the wrong direction. We have had no clear explanation as yet from the government as to why it is proposing in item 8 of schedule 3 the move from 75 per cent to 66 per cent. The government should explain to the House the rationale that the government and the cabinet are advancing. PAIRS We believe these share schemes should be as broad based and as inclusive as possible. Moving from 75 per cent to 66 per cent is a step in the opposite direction, and for that reason it is opposed by the Australian Labor Party.

Title: NOES
text: Werriwa) (4.56 p.m.)Could I just ask the extent of consultation the government has had with employee associations. It is all right to say that the captains of industry regard this as more viable. They undoubtedly will be in the invitation, whether it is 66 per cent or 75 per cent. I would like to hear from the government as to whether or not their consultation went beyond the captains of industry and actually got to the shop floor to consult with the average working Australians who will be affected by this change. Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: NOES
text: The Labor Party has no opposition from its readof the ing of the amendments, but we would have thought it was respectful to the House to have some explanation of them by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles). It is not too often by a decent Westminster standard that legislative amendments are moved and then the mover sits down. Normally, there is some explanation. I do not know if the advisers, who are looking anxious, provided the relevant notes, but at least they should be recited to the House. I would invite the parliamentary secretary to do so. Can the House of Representatives have some explanation of the government's reasons for these amendments on issues that have invited an enormous amount of public controversy, not least of all from the Australian Society of CPAs, which has been very critical of the government's proposed rollover relief for capital gains tax? If these amendments are the answer to those criticisms, then in terms of public accountability and, most importantly, accountability to the chamber, the government should have some explanation of what it is doing. Have you something to say?

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: Whilst we are dealing with schedules 4 and 5 together and the government's amendments to them, I will try to break up my remarks a little to give the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) an opportunity, if he wishes to take it, to respond to some concerns I have with the detail. They are not only my concerns, I might add; they are also those expressed by the Taxation Institute of Australia and the Corporate Taxpayers Association. They have told me that they do not accept the view, when talking about schedule 4, major underlining interests, that the concept of backdating from the date of an unusual trade has always been part of the framework of section 160ZZS or its administration. I did touch on that in my speech in the second reading debate and I referred to an income tax ruling by the commissioner. I have already made that point, but I do not think, in summing up the second reading debate, that it was addressed. The parliamentary secretary may be able to comment on that. Furthermore, the two bodies to which I have already referred are not of a mind to accept that it is appropriate for schedule 4 to specify dates by which underlying ownership analysis should be completed to impose substantial sanction where this does not otherwise occur. They are also very toey about the reservation being provided at the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation to override the one per cent notional shareholder test. Furthermore, they make the point more than adequately that the definitions of abnormal trading are excessively broad. I might go into that in a little detail, depending on the way this debate goes. The TIA and the Corporate Taxpayers Association support the use of 'reasonable approximation' testing as at a date proximate to 20 September 1985 and similar flexibility, in their view, should be allowed in respect of subsequent testing dates. Still on schedule 4, perhaps I could refer to the transitional provisions as speIt out in section 160ZZSA. These appear to be circular to say the least. Section 160ZZSA(1)(b) seems to exclude the new regime whenever section 160ZZS(1) has been attracted prior to 20 January 1997. But subsequent provisions appear to proceed on a contrary assumption. For example, section 160ZZSC(4) presupposes that the new regime may apply in cases where a prior public ruling imposed a requirement to test and that the test would have been failed prior to 20 January 1997. The intention appears to have been to exclude the new regime only in cases where there has already been an adverse determination under section 160ZZS and that the taxpayers involved have conceded that it applies. In all other cases, it would appear that it is intended that matters can be dealt with and, if necessary, determined independently by the commissioner under sections 160ZZSC(3) and 160ZZSC(4). The new regime imposes a positive obligation to 'make a determination by an examination of its records showing whether majority underlying interests' were relevantly held. (Extension of time granted) The drafting presupposes that the determination will yield either a yes or no answer. The reality may well be that such matters remain unclear, notwithstanding all the diligence that can be reasonably required and expected within the period allowed. In those cases, the company may be unable to make any determination. That might be through lack of information or merely uncertainty concerning the effect of the provision. In short, it is inappropriate to assume in such cases that the company should make an adverse determination. The failure to make a determination leads to not inconsequential outcomes for the taxpayer. The purpose or effect of requiring by examination of its records is worthy of some further consideration and clarification. For example, is the intention that the basis for determination be limited to an examination of corporate records and, if so, when? That sort of limitation may well be inappropriate. Is the intention that there be no right or obligation to go beyond records? I would like to quote direct from written information I have from the Taxation Institute of Australia. They say: Where the company fails duly to make a determination within the time allowed, the test is effectively deemed to have been failed at the commencement of the test period. The penalties or consequences which flow from this will often be inappropriate. Thus (for example) if a company fails to make a determination as at 20 January 1997, it is deemed to have acquired the asset on 20 September 1985 for a consideration equal to the market value on that date. That would be entirely inappropriate if the failure arises because the company is unable to make the determination, or fails to do so because it is not aware of an abnormal trading triggering event. It would also lead to entirely inappropriate results if, for example, the test had clearly been satisfied up to December 1985 (and had appreciated in value to that time) but it was unclear whether or not it was satisfied thereafter. The risk of such an outcome could be worse than any risk of application of Sec. 160ZZS(1 ). It is also not in accord the principle espoused in the Budget Papers which was that the amendments would defer the date at which assets lose their pre-CGT status from the date when the majority underlying ownership changed to the time when the test of underlying ownership is required to be conducted. The institute goes on: The determination must be made within the 'prescribed period' which is defined as a period generally of 6 months duration. This period may well prove to be insufficient and unworkable. Where an adverse determination is made at 20 January 1997, the consequences may depend on whether or not the entity was 'required before 20 January 1997 under a ruling' to apply the tests under Sec. 160ZZS ... (3) and (4). Presumably the rulings to which this refers are IT253"O and IT2361. In cases where such rulings required that a test be made, Subsec.(4) should make it clear that the 'abnormal trading' or other events triggering the need to test supply the determination time. The institute goes on to demonstrate that the definitions of 'abnormal trading' have the very real potential to operate in circumstances which rulings 2530 and 2361 would not have been regarded as requiring that the test be made and, as a consequence, it may give rise to considerable uncertainty. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: NOES
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (5.12 p.m.)-Some of the issues which the previous speaker was referring to are obviously issues which require judgment and really go to some political judgment issues. Some of the others which the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has raised I am very happy to seek advice on from the Treasurer (Mr Costello). On two things which he raised in regard to the Corporate Taxpayers Association and the Tax Institute of Australia, the government does not agree that there is no change in policy to the old section 160ZZS. In regard to the definition of 'abnormal trade', we believe that the CTA issue there is too narrow. Of course, that is a judgment which has to be made in these matters.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: I thank the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles). I am not sure whether he is aware of the detail of the TIA's concern, but the definition of 'abnormal with trading' does bear looking at. I do not think it is just a matter for judgment; I think it is a matter of equity and perhaps even of this element of the legislation operating as intended. The definition of 'abnormal trading', as proposed, might lead to it being contended that the only trading which can qualify as normal trading is trading which occurs on a stock exchange and then only if the volume is within a very narrow range. Should that be the case, the allotment of shares, however small, might be regarded as requiring that a test be made. That gets to the point, which the parliamentary secretary, I am sure, will be interested in, that allotments under employee share plans-also referred to in another schedule in this legislation-or dividend reinvestment plans might trigger these provisions. Allotment of shares, on the basis that it was abnormal, or that they might trigger the provision that it was abnormal, or on the basis that involves five per cent of the shares-although it does not alter the underlying interests at all-is part of the problem. The width of the definitions for abnormal trading, read in conjunction with the consequences of failure to make a determination, make further inappropriate results quite likely. The determination, in fact, might not be made because the company is simply unaware of facts subsequently contended to constitute abnormal trade. That is where you get into problems, once again, with giving the commissioner discretion. The interplay-I noted the assurance of the parliamentary secretary and for which I am grateful-of ITs 2530 and 2361 is presently constituted. The end result is that a failure to make a determination results in a failure of the tests under 160ZZS. I see that that may not be in the mind of the parliamentary secretary and, therefore, the government and is a matter of concern. I do not know if the parliamentary secretary wants to answer that or if I could go on to something slightly relevant, but in the same vein. Mr Miles-Keep going.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: Where the capital shareholding is less than one per cent, at the end of the day, section 160ZZSQ reserves to the Commissioner of Taxation a discretion to disregard subdivisions providing special rules for holdings of less than one per cent. That strikes me as being totally inappropriate in light of the history-some of which I have touched on-referring to the commissioner's rulings under present legislation. The special rules for holdings of less than one per cent are intended to provide the basis on which the rules are saved from being unworkable. They also provide the major criteria on which the new regime can be said to assist -.;, rporates. This section, 160ZZSQ, effectively empowers the commissioner to withdraw these features while leaving in place the 'various aspects of the legislation which have the effect of making changes in policy applied to the section which are adverse to taxpayers. The TIA says, in this context, that the provisions obviate the need to trace through complying superannuation funds. It would be preferable if these provisions were excluded to foreign superannuation funds and not noncomplying funds. (Extension of time granted) This will conclude my remarks under schedule 4, unless the parliamentary secretary in response raises something worthy of further comment. The need for rulings in respect of which such rulings are necessary if the new regime is to have prospects of operating fairly are of interest. For example, there are a number of provisions which provided for the exercise of discretions on the part of the commissionersome of which I have referred to-and I would refer the parliamentary secretary to sections 160ZZSA3B, 160ZZSC(2) and 160ZZSD(2) in addition to 160ZZSQ. It was previously understood by the TIA that rulings would be made available in relation to the exercise of various discretions as long ago as last December. That understanding was arrived at last December. They seem to be under the impression that the rulings would specifically address matters such as the used dates reasonably approximate to 20 September 1985 and application of the old regime recognising a safe harbour where past events are not captured by the new rules. They and I urge that drafts of these rulings be made available for comment as a matter of priority and preferably while the legislation is still before the parliament, albeit the Senate.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: NOES
text: In capital my second reading contribution to the Taxsay ation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4), I raised the concerns of the Australian Society CPAs about the capital gains tax rollover relie- provisions. If not, what revision g.overnment provide to the quantity of concesSIon that the parliament is now examining? r.wr ROCHER (Curtin) (5.24 p.m.)-I am gomg on to the capital rollover stuff.
