Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I hope you do not mind us making these informal arrangements. It is easier. My interest in schedule 5 arises out of the length and complexity of the bill. There are 26 pages dealing with the small business gains tax rollover concession. I would that the complexity has in very considerable measure subverted the government's of policy intentions in this area. The major reason for the length and compl-xity of the legislation seems to be a perceIved need to quarantine goodwill from the other assets of a taxpayer's business-in tum, to prevent small businesses from rolling over a capital gain from the disposal of goodwill into a non-goodwill replacement asset. This seems to be because there is a fear that might try to convert a capital gainfor example, a building development-and shift it into a business with excess goodwill and then claim the partial goodwill exemption for that goodwill. If someone sets out to do that, the general anti-avoidance provisions of part 4A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 would undoubtedly apply. This is an example of how the provisions have been made unduly complex by the inclusion of unnecessary words. The Taxation Institute of Australia on this matter, had this to say: ., The problem is that the Bill now leaves the genuine with no effective rollover relief. For example. someone who has built up a business nothing. so that the assets of the business will be predominantly goodwill. and who wants to attempt to tum around a moribund business where the goodwill may be worth very little. will be locked out of the concession. It is unfortunate that with the introduction of the new rollover provision. the opportunity was not taken to align it and the partial goodwill exemption provision. What policy reason can there be for the different thresholds and differing rules about can the associated businesses. Further, there are a number of conditions limiting the value of proposed rollover to businesses which will ultimately discourage business from seeking to make use of it. Why, for example, must current and prior year losses be first offset? Why indeed. That is not a general requirement for other rollover provisions, and its reason for inclusion in these provisions is obscure to say the least.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: NOES
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (5.27 p.m.)-I would like to respond to the Australian Society of CPA's comment about being hoodwinked. I think that comment came out on Tuesday, 4 March of this week in an article which responded to the fine print of the so-called CGT rollover relief. Mark Abernethy says: Central to Mr Hayes' concern is the exclusionary nature of the CGT relief. On the surface, the relief seeI?ed open to sole traders, partnerships, companIes and trusts. But a closer reading of the bill showed the majority of Australia's more substantial small businesses would not be eligible. Our response to that is that the provisions that apply are regardless of the structure used to run a small business. For a sole trader in a partnership, the rollover relief is available at the individual level. For a company, the rollover relief is available at the company level. For a trust, the rollover relief is available at the trustee level. This treatment merely reflects the government's announcement that rollover relief will apply to a direct interest in an asset. With regard to partnerships, if one partner buys out another partner in a twoperson partnership, the selling partner can get the rollover relief if the partner buys a new business, either as a partner in a new partnership or as a sole trader.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: NOES
text: -The point that has been doubted by the Society of CPAs on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4) is whether the government is standing by its $215 million costing. This was also doubted, in very effective terms, by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his second reading contribution earlier in the debate. If the government is standing by that amountif that is the costing and the amount of relief to be provided--can it also provide a guarantee to the House in terms of the integrity of the tax system? It is my understanding that Treasury officials have advised the government of their concerns about the way in which some of these provisions might be open to abuse and - ax minim-sation. I believe it is always very Important In a debate looking at a new form of tax concession to consider the flip side-a flip side that the average working PAYE taxpayer is always concerned about; that is, that the corporate sector in Australia is not bein- opened up for the possibility of shonky practIce and that the government is standing as guardian of the integrity of the tax system. That is a very important guarantee for the government to provide in this debate, particularly when a number of parliamentarians have been made aware of concerns expressed within the bureaucracy. I would ask the parliamentary secretary if he could clarify those two matters. Does the government stand by the $215 million costing after the amendments that have been carried earlier and the public critique that has been offered by a number of organisations? And, if it is standing by the $215 million, does it also offer a guarantee to the House in terms of the integrity of the Australian taxation system?

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: NOES

But we have looked at that and we stand by the integrity of the system. Amendments agreed to. Schedules, as amended, agreed to. Remainder of bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to. Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: This is a continuation of my speech before I was so conveniently interrupted by emergence of question time today. I am pleased to see, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, that you are in the chair because, before the question time break, ,!,e actually had the effect of inducing you Into the House. What do we see here now when we are debating the bounties legislation, which is going to see jobs lost in all sorts regions around the country? Not one government backbencher in the place; not one. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr .Moore), who is at the table, is pointing to hImself. He has to be here. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) reckons he has had the - ffect of changing your decision, but where IS the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes)? She has not come in in all of this debate. The member for Bendigo is prepared to come into this chamber and at least stand up for w.hat he thinks he has done-not very e-fectIvely-but the member for Kingston is stIll not here. Let me remind the House of what she said. Yesterday she urged the government to be more critical of the advice it received i- preparing its second budget and that cuts to Industry assistance in last year's budget had already hurt the state. That, indeed they have. This is one of those cuts. This is - cut to the book bounty. It has cost 300 Jobs-and the minister laughs at it-at Griffin Press al(;me. bec--se of their inability to plan - d theIr InabIlIty to deal with a secure Investment environment because this government unilaterally cut the bounty from under their feet. The fact is-and it is important because you are in the chair, Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER - that these issues of cutting the bounty were always attempted and put up to us by Treasury. But as a government we resisted them. There were attempts to reduce these measures in the so called interests of the level playing fieldwhich does not exist. We all want to get there but we are not there now. What we have is a government proposing unilateral disarmament flying in the face of what is happening in threst of the world and expecting our industry to be able to cope. The simple reality is that these firms could compete with overseas countries if those overseas countries did not have support and assistance. That is the truth. They are world competitive. But what they cannot do is compete and get into markets that are restricted to them in those countries. I can remember the circumstances in relation to book publishing where people in this country would lament every time they picked up a new publication which said 'Printed in of Singapore' - printed somewhere else, printed everywhere except Australia. Australians are some of the most avid readers in the world yet we .coul.d not get a book publishing Industry In thIS country until Labor introduced a plan for the book industry. It did so by - u.ppo- through research and development InItIatIves as well as the book bounty-the bounty to level the playing field, the R&D to get them to invest in state-of-the-art technology. But these are programs that this government has come in and slashed, regardless of the consequences. It believes it has got to pursue the budget bottom line rather than consider the consequences. It has established a Productivity Commission, but it will not give it legislative teeth to have regard to the impact on regional economies or to have regard to what our trading partners are doing when it comes to their level of assistance and support. We say that has to change. The member for Bendigo, who is in the chair, has recognised it has to change. It is just that he is impotent in getting that change. He says he has taken representations to the minister. If you have taken representations and been successful to date, as you claim, Mr Deputy Speaker, take some more submissions-because the industry is telling you. If you go and visit Maryborough, they will tell you they want this decision restored, that they want it to the end of next year-and Labor supports the extra six months. But it is also entitled to an inquiry that regard to what is happening in the rest of the world, that has regard to how an industry can continue to position itself. If there is any commitment to regional development, to the people of Maryborough and the people of Adelaide who depend on this industry for jobs, support our amendment. I call on the member for Bendigo, when he is out of the chair, and the member for Kingston to come in and vote with us. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: In addressing the bounty legislation this afternoon I am fearful that tomorrow's press in Bendigo will basically have a front page story going to the failure of the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) to vote for local electorate jobs. I am really concerned about this because it is an important issue to have the front page of the local papers in Bendigo tomorrow with a banner across the front 'Reid votes against Bendigo electorate jobs'. That is what it is really about: will the member for Bendigo vote for local jobs or will he walk away from his responsibilities? The proposition that we are in support of is very simple: the government proposes that the book bounty be abolished from 1 July rather than 20 August. So far as we are concerned, that is six months short of the original expiry date established by the Australian Labor Party. That expiry date was established in consultation with local industry in places such as Maryborough, South Australia and Queensland. It is about saying to those local employers, 'If you are prepared to give it a go, then we are prepared to give you a go.' We are basically saying that we are prepared to provide the necessary assistance to ensure that you are capable of growing on the export front and as part and parcel of that export growth, capable of providing additional jobs in areas of high need. It is not just places such as Bendigo that we are talking about. We are also talking about Queensland. Let us have a look at some of the high unemployment levels that currently exist in Queensland. I know the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) is not too interested in these facts. As at January 1997 what was unemployment in the northhas west of Queensland? It was 10.6 per cent. In the Rockhampton area it was 11.6 per cent and in Far North Queensland around Cairns it was 8.9 per cent-all above the national average. That is why I put it to the House that it is wrong to abolish these industry bounties, especially for the state of Queensland, the minister's home state. The abolition of these industry bounties will take Australia in the opposite direction from what is needed for its development at the moment. I suggest that, if this legislation is passed, Queensland businesses-and it will be on the head of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourismwill lose nearly $7 million.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: I know it might be a joke to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, better known on the other side of the House as the bagman. We are talking about a loss of $7 million to the state of Queensland for businesses of all sizes, including small businesses.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: BOUNTY LEGISLATION
text: The minister for small business might think it is a joke, he might think job growth is a joke, but I think it is about time that the minister for small business, rather than interjecting, faced up to the fact that he is an abject failure with respect to his performance to date. He has not done a thing to try to create an environment for investment and jobs growth in Australia. In Queensland we are talking about a loss of $7 million a year in assistance from the federal government. Do you know what it means for businesses in Queensland? Some 251 Queensland businesses benefited from the industry bounty scheme in the last financial year, not an insignificant number when you are talking about high unemployment-such as in Rockhampton-of the order of 11.6 per cent. These are secondary industries that are needed to further develop that state. They are needed to broaden its industrial base. They are needed in places such as Townsville, Cairns and Rockhampton. I am waiting to see how the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), how the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) and how the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) vote on this amendment. They have a lot to say locally, but when they get to Canberra it is almost as if they have their feet tied together when it comes to standing up for their local electorates. They go missing in action. That is what it is about: they are not prepared to stand and fight for a decent industry policy that assists in creating job opportunities in their local regions. They are the big losers-not only with respect to the bounty legislation but they have already lost on the closure of the CES offices; and they have lost as a result of the increase in HECS payments and with respect to changes in Telstra and the loss of local jobs in the service centres. So I think it is about time they said that enough is enough. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has to be stood up and told the hard facts of life-that, as far as we are concerned, jobs are the order of the day. Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: PAIRS
text: by leave-I move government amendments Nos 2 and 3: (2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (line 24), omit "21 May 1997", substitute" 1 October 1997". (3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 32), omit "21 May 1997", substitute "1 October 1997". These amendments are consequent on the government's decision to extend the termination date of the book bounty. The amendments introduce an absolute end date of 30 September 1997 for book bounty claims, 90 days after the end of the bounty period proposed in the previous amendment. This will ensure that the administration of the scheme is wound up quickly and that the majority of payments for eligible productions are made as soon as possible after the end of the period of the eligible production. I commend the amendments to the House.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: It is true that these are consequential amendments. They are consequential on the government betraying the book publishing industry in this country by abolishing a bounty for them, by being forced to reverse that decision, but to only partially proceed down the reversal route. We are saying that the book bounty should be extended by another six months. This government has just voted against that and there are people who should have voted on this side, like the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes), who still is not in this chamber, who still will not come in and defend her actions. She still will not come in and tell us why she is prepared to go to the Adelaide Advertiser and complain about the cuts to industry programs but will not come into this chamber and stand up for the people of Kingston. We also have the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who is still in the chair. He can at least claim that he abstained on the last vote because he was protected by the chair.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Order! You are casting a reflection on the role that I play in the chamber.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: I withdraw the reflection. I simply make the point that you were missing in action in New York last year when it was time for standing up for the book publishing industry. We would hope that you would actually exercise a vote in favour of the people of Maryborough in your electorate, a quarter of the work force of which town depends on this book bounty. It is an industry that did not exist before Labor introduced the book bounty, an industry where, if you ever wanted to read a book in this country, you opened the first page and found that it was printed in some overseas country. The fact of the matter is this was an uncompetitive country and it could not get into the game because all the other countries were supporting their book publishing industry. Labor introduced a two-pronged attack: it said, 'Invest in the technology and we'll give you tax deductions for it.' As a government they have wiped out the tax deductions despite the fact they went to the last election promising to keep them. Broken promise, bad policy-two bad hits. But then we also had the book bounty, which we were always being told we had to get rid of. The member for Bendigo made reference to this earlier-that Labor trotted out a plan to get rid of the book bounty itself. It is true that the bureaucrats put that forward, but we opposed it. It did not come and it did not get passed. If it had have been passed, why would we be debating the issue today? So for you to come in and say that we voted down the books bounty. back in 1993 is just plain wrong because, if it were true, we would not be debating this issue now. Let us understand that the only people who put book publishing on the map in this country were Labor: Labor through the books bounty, Labor through industry support. Labor has seen the growth of this industry, an industry which has seen a doubling of exports in the space of time in which it has been in place, an industry which previously saw non-existent jobs growth. There has been 200 per cent export growth over the past 12 years that this plan has been in place under Labor, and it has taken them six months to abolish it, despite the fact they told no-one during the election campaign they would do it. I would have liked to have seen Deputy Speaker Reid out campaigning in Maryborough saying, 'Have we got a plan for you when we get into government. We are going to get rid of the books bounty, which is going to wipe out a quarter of the work force in Maryborough.' That would have been a great campaign! But he did not say that, of course; he said quite the opposite. He said, 'We're going to keep it,' and then he comes along and is part of the decision to abolish it. It is a disgrace. We have the member for Kingston shedding crocodile tears in today's Adelaide Advertiser saying, 'Cuts to industry assistance in last year's budget already hurt the state,' but will she be in the House today? She has not attended except to vote, and then she voted the wrong way. She is inconsistent the posi,tion she talks about in the press and inconsistent in representing her constituents in this chamber. The facts of the matter are that Labor is the only party that has been prepared to support the book publishing industry in this country and it is the coalition which has come along as the new vandals-wreck the industry, wreck regions and put them at the mercy of the international marketplace where there is no such thing as a level playing field.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: Is it not amazing to hear the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) speak about promises? You see, there was an election prior to the last one where the Liberal Party and the coalition went to the people with a brand newMr Crean-Have you ever read a book?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: Go and check my time at Perth Modem School, which would never have let you in. I got there by winning a scholarship, so do not worry about that, you dope. Mr Crean-I am deeply offended and I ask him to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: I would because I can think of worse things he is.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Order! The honourable member would help the House if he directed his remarks through the chair. Mr Crean-Did you? Has he withdrawn, Mr Deputy Speaker?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Yes. Mr Crean-I did not hear him say that.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: I withdrew, now you sit down. The reality is that promises were made-and supported by the shadow minister at the table in the election prior to the last one-that there would be no new taxes, but that it was the dreadful coalition that was going to restructure taxation to give the book industry, to give the motor car industry and to give everybody else a tax regime that at that time would have, for instance, taken $700 or $800 out of the manufactured cost of a motor car. They stood up and said, 'You don't need anything of that and, what's more, we will give you l-a-w tax cuts without imposing any additional taxation at all.' What did you do? You came to office, you cancelled the l-a-w tax cuts and you imposed 6c a litre on distillate fuels and you tell us about decentralisation. What is the worse tax you can put on decentralisation? Fuel tax. Mr Crean- Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, and it relates to relevance. For the purposes of the member for O'Connor, this is a debate about the books bounty. He has not yet once mentioned books or the impact of this decision and you should get him to speak to the issue.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: There is no point of order. I have been listening closely to the member for O'Connor. This has been a far ranging contribution, as the member for Hotham and the member for Batman know, but I do invite the member for O'Connor to return to the text of the bill.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: At the very point of interruption, I was making the point about decentralised industry. I kept hearing the shadow minister carrying on about your decentralised electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the electorate of Kingston in South Australia, which is quite distant from all the major markets of Melbourne and Sydney. Quite clearly, book producers and book printers have to transport large quantities of paper to their premises and, of course, redistribute those books and they use road transport. The first thing that the Keating government did was put a special tax on that transport. The man is so dull that he does not think transport affects the efficiency of industries throughout Australia. He is winding his finger around saying it does not matter. The problem is that I think you believe that transport has no effect on Australian industry. It has been said by some of your colleagues on occasions that it represents about one dollar in every seven that Australians are obliged to spend. You put a substantial tax on it after the election where you promised no tax increases at all. Do not come in here with your arguments about consistency. I used to say of the Democrats that you cannot buy them, you can only rent them by the hour. That is the statement that I am going to use about you people in future because the Democrats might be socialists, but at least they have become consistent. Mr Crean-On a point of order: the member is required to address all of his remarks through the chair. I would ask you to draw his attention to that standing order and ask him to comply with it.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PAIRS
text: I am delighted to do so. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the members of the Labor Party are best described these days as having so much integrity that you cannot buy them, you can only rent them by the hour. An hour is probably longer than anyone of your current policies would survive. You are outrageous in that regard. The book industry would be much better off without your fuel tax. It would be a lot better off without your $10,000 million interest charge that appeared in the budget and which would allow all sorts of financial assistance to be given in all sorts of areas. That is impossible as the government of today is obliged to address the $80,000 million of additional debt that you added to the budget bottom line. (Time expired) Amendments agreed to. Items, as amended, agreed to. Items 4 and 5-by leave-taken together.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: I thought we were actually going to get something of an explanation from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), but as always he is quick to cut the programs and never explain. We now have the computer bounty. The coalition government made a core promise during the election to retain the computer bounty. This promise was clearly made because it was something that the Labor Party committed to do and committed to keep running until the year 2000. What did they do in their first budget? They broke that promise comprehensively. Now this is one of the areas that has not yet seen a reversal of form. This area plus the machine tools and robots areas have not got any relief or respite yet. Books and ships have, but not enough, and computers and machine tools and robots have not. Where, might we ask, is the consistency in that position? Do you know what the consistency is, Mr Deputy Speaker? There has been a more effective lobbying campaign run to date by the shipbuilders and book publishers in this country than there has been by the computer and machine tools and robots industries. We will still keep pursuing their interests because certainty has been taken from them. Understand that you have a computer industry in this country which has invested massively in research and development, massively in exports, massively in production and we have seen huge growth in all of those areas of activity. For example, in the last five years exports of information technology related products have trebled in this country. That has occurred because there was a certain regime introduced by Labor-a regime that was built around the partnerships for development program and included the computer bounty and the R&D concessions. Under the partnerships for development program there was a requirement for firms entering into the program to commit to levels of growth in production, R&D and exports. All of those targets and commitments have been met until now. Why will they not be met now? Because the government deceived this industry during the last election by promising to retain the bounty. It wiped it OUt-3V2 years in one fell swoop. It also reduced the tax deductibility from 150 per cent to 125 per cent with the minister saying, 'You should be thankful because it could have gone to 100 per cent.' His defence was, 'I have really saved you because the cuts could have been worse.' This level of growth would not have occurred had it not been for the plan and the certainty introduced by Labor. The simple fact of the matter is that the manufacturing industry has grown in this country. We have seen huge growth in the exports of certain key industries-the information technology industry being amongst them-but it only happened because there was a plan behind those industries. What does the industry itself have to say about the government's decision? Mr Neville Roach, the Managing Director of Fujitsu, wrote to us saying: Both the present government and its predecessor supported the extension of the computer bounty as recently as 1995. This bipartisan support only came after a long and exhaustive period of consultation between the industry and government. Both recognised that the bounty is not a subsidy but rather compensation to local manufacturers for additional component cost and they result from other decisions that the government had taken. This was addressing market failure. This was recognising that, if the industry was to grow, it had to have this market failure addressed. The minister is on record as saying that he recognises the need to intervene where there is market failure. Well, he recognises the need to intervene, but he has cut away the intervention. Some intervention! You recognise the problem, but you are not prepared to address the cure. It is no wonder you have had criticism from this industry. We believe this is also an area that has to be reversed. The government has to return to the commitment they made during the election and support the local information technology industry. We will be persisting with this measure to get that reversal. (Extension of time granted) What we have got is the circumstance in which there is no commitment from the minister to support an industry, though it was his promise, his policy. He went to the last election saying it. No doubt he went to his le-der and said, 'This is a vital area to secure because there are lots of employees in the manufacturing sector in computers, and we've got to keep them onside. We don't want to frighten anyone during the election campaign.' The minister went and sold the promise. He put it out in public terms in a document and said, 'We will keep the computer bounty.' Do you deny that, Minister? I know you will not get up and speak in this debate, because your position is indefensible. Mr Moore interjecting

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: The minister says he relies on Keating. This is the person who said, 'We're going to lift standards.' This is the person who said, 'We're going to do it differently to Labor.' I tell you what: the commitments we made in terms of industry support were honoured. That is the reason why the manufacturing industry in this country had started to grow and had started to contribute. The minister might be interested in looking at today's national accounts figures because they address the question of production over a the last quarter. The manufacturing sector has seen a 2.6 per cent reduction in outputs. That has occurred because of the policies that you put in place as a result of the budget. There is no point saying to the industry, as the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) would have us believe, that you have got interest rates down or you have done these other things if in fact you are putting them out of the game. There is no way they will stay in it. If you are undermining these industries by stripping away the mechanisms by which their exports have grown, then what you are doing is really denying this country the opportunity for significant, huge advances. The fact of the matter is that the minister has made a commitment. The only target the government has set, I might add, is a target of 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing. But every time the minister has been asked in this place to tell us what his strategy is to get there, he has not done it. He has not even asked his department to produce a strategy for it. How are you going to achieve it when, in one quarter alone, you have had a decline in manufacturing production by a massive 2.6 per cent? You come into this place and claim that everything is doing well in terms of the national accounts and that growth is on course, but growth is going down and manufacturing production has gone into the negative. Mr Moore--It has gone up.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PAIRS
text: It has not gone up. Have a look at the figures yourself, if you are capable of interpreting them. Manufacturing production has gone down by 2.6 per cent in the last quarter. It is no coincidence that that reduction has occurred against the backdrop of the massive cuts to industry programs. It is no wonder the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) is telling you through today's Adelaide Advertiser that the cuts to industry assistance in last year's budget have already hurt her state. They have not only hurt that state; they have hurt the nation-and they have hurt it to the tune of a reduction in manufacturing production. How are you going to get jobs if you have got reductions in production in the manufacturing sector? I ask you that. Where do you think these jobs are going to come from? Unless you have the supportive framework and the certainty that encourages industries to invest and to make the commitment to continue to get into those overseas markets, it simply will not materialise. I believe we have a minister in this chamber who is incapable of getting a message through and incapable of winning an argument in his cabinet. He has fallen for the view that he has to deliver budget cuts at any cost, but the costs are horrendous. They are costs to jobs, they are costs to regions and they are costs to exports. Why would you get rid of a program that saw an increase in exports and an increase in jobs? I thought the priority of this government was twofold-to correct the current account deficit and to increase job opportunities. Here you have a program that did both of those things, and they have axed it-but it is not the only area which has been axed. This is another massive betrayal of Australia's manufacturing industry. This is a government that pretends to have the interests of industry at heart but will do nothing for them. This is a government that has been condemned by those same industry groups. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: PAIRS
text: I, like the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), am concerned about what we regard as a blatant decision by the present government to break what I thought was a fairly fundamental promise made by the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) prior to the election just on 12 months ago. I refer to the fact that, during the election campaign-and I am sure the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) was consulted; after all, he is the Prime Minister's number cruncher-the coalition matched Labor's commitment to retain the computer bounty to the end of the year 2000. I think that was a fairly important commitment. It was made in good faith, and industry took that commitment on board-as did a lot of workers and their families who depended on that commitment for the purposes of their job security and their ability in the end to look after their families. I know the Prime Minister likes to talk from time to time about the question of security-security at work, security at home, security in the community at large. But the problem is that, since the election, the Prime Minister has decided that your word is not your bond. That is what he has decided. With respect to the computer bounty and their undertaking that it shall prevail until the year 2000, your word is no longer your bond. What does the government say is the justification to achieve so-called savings? As the minister said in his second reading speech, the savings are to be achieved through the termination of the computer bounty with effect from 1 July this year. He then goes on to suggest that these bounty schemes have run their course. I suggest to the House that these bounty schemes have not run their course. I will tell you why: the level of unemployment in Australia suggests that they have not run their course. The problem for the government-and it is walking away from its responsibilities-is that not only is unemployment a major problem at the moment, but it is especially a huge problem in regional Australia and is especially a huge problem for the long-term unemployed. In that context, there is a role for government to involve itself in assisting industry; there is a role for government to involve itself in regional Australia; and there is a role for government to involve itself in trying to push and prod industry. The government needs to encourage industry to invest and to create decent job opportunities-real job opportunities-not half-baked suggestions or proposals as brought forward by the Prime Minister just on a week and a half ago with respect to the work for the dole scheme. If there are any real concerns about these issues, I refer the House to the fact that, in seasonally adjusted terms, the numbers of long-term unemployed rose from 229,500 in December to 232,700 in January. The minister wants the House to accept that the schemes have run their course. I do not accept that the schemes have run their course when you have 232,700 people in Australia who are long term unemployed. It is interesting that there are hoW 30,100 more long-term unemployed Australians than in May 1996 when the Howard government began cutting decent labour market programs, induding Skillshare, throughout the length and breadth of Australia. These schemes have not run their course. Australian industry expects support. The bounty scheme that prevailed in the computer industry encouraged industry to make investments, because a company's ability to make investments depends on a sense of stability and security. It is on that basis that companies are prepared to make mediumto long-term investment decisions. The coalition had a clear commitment prior to the federal election that the computer bounty scheme would exist through to 2000 and on the basis of that commitment they made decisions. They were prepared to put their money up-front for the purposes of investing in Australia, for the purposes 0; securing export growth and for the purposes of securing for a large number of Australian families a sense of job security. I think it is high time that the minister stood up to the Prime Minister and said in no uncertain terms, 'Where I come from in Queensland, the Liberal Party way is to honour your word. Your word is your bond. A commitment to the Australian electorate to make sure that this scheme existed through to 2000 should prevail. We should not break our word. We should ensure that industry continues to have a sense of security and on that basis they can continue to plan their investment opportunities for the future.' Motion (by Dr Wooldridge) proposed: That the requested amendments be not made.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: I will try to make this as brief as possible. These are opposition amendments. Basically, these amendments simply seek to provide for automatic indexation of the income thresholds at which the private health insurance tax rebate cuts out. Reading through the Senate Hansard, there was a bit of confusion about whether our amendments were going to index the value of the tax rebate or whether they would index the income threshold at which the rebates cut out. Everyone who has studied this knows that it is about how we index the income limits. That is why the proposed index is average weekly earnings. I will not dwell average weekly earnings for the immediately preceding calendar year average weekly earnings for calendar year 1996 on that, but that is the point that these amendments go to. I have two questions, Minister, that I will go through very quickly. One was that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary for the Attorney-General (Senator Ellison) in the Senate said that one of the reasons the amendments could not be accepted was that there is no provision for them in the forward estimates. I would have expected that the forward estimates are based on a certain number of people having private insurance. I thought in the past we had spoken about a figure of 35.5 per cent. Given that there are now only 33.2 per cent of people who have private health insurance, I would have thought there is a bit of fat in the forward estimates. Unless there is a sudden jump in the number of people with private health insurance on 1 July, there will be a bit of fat in those forward estimates which would allow, perhaps, the funding of this automatic indexation. If I am wrong, I am happy to tap the mat on that. Perhaps we can deal with that question first.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.41 p.m.)My understanding is that we are dealing with the best figures we have so far, in the December quarter. We cannot really predict what will happen by the two quarters hence. There is no fat that I am aware of. I am informed that the cost over four years of doing this would be $73 million. While I can see the merit in doing it, what we have attempted to do is simply implement what we promised before the election. Honestly, if I had another $73 million, I would probably be spending it on another area of need in health. I feel we have more than acquitted our undertaking to the Australian community by implementing what we propose to do. I note in passing that similar indexation arrangements were not promised in the Labor Party's election proposal. To the best of my knowledge, there is no fat and I do not have the capacity to make that without offsetting It 1D the rest of my portfolio-$73 million over four years is a substantial amount to offset.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: A brief debating point first, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the minister believes that an extra $73 million could be better spent in other areas of the portfolio rather than in providing tax breaks for private health insurance, I am wonder whether he is willing to now accept the opposition's point that perhaps the whole $1.7 billion could have been better spent in paying for extra operations in public and private hospitals or in other areas of private health care. I do not think I will persuade him on that point, but I thought he left me an opening on that. Finally, concerning the second question I spoke about before, at various times we have been trying to find out what the government's intentions are about the thresholds. I think we have been told that, if at some future time the government wanted to increase these income thresholds, it could do so by introducing legislation and amending the act. At one point I think we were told incorrectly in the Senate that this could be done by regulation, but my understanding is that it will require an amendment to the act and so we would be seeking to know from the minister whether the government is planning to change the thresholds. That is a crucial point. Are you planning to change the thresholds that apply to this Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1996?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.44 p.m.)On the debating point, without carrying it too far, the whole of the $1.7 billion is being spent to implement a core election promise, and we keep our promises. There are no plans to increase the thresholds at this stage. It does not mean we would not do it; it means that we really have, only in the most early stages, started considering the 1997-98 budget. I do not say at a future date we will not do it but, like Medicare levy thresholds under the previous government, they were not indexed but they were increased from time to time as a policy decision. We have no plans to do that at the moment. That does not mean we will not do it at some stage in the future.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: We are disappointed. We thought we might have been able to persuade the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) to accept our very reasonable proposals on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No.2) 1996 as well. Once again, this seeks to index the income limits at which the Medicare levy cuts in if people do not have private health insurance. We believe that it is only fair that this income limit be maintained in real terms. The minister might remember that, in the debate on these matters previously, I did express concern that at the next budget the government might bring in a proposal to lower the threshold, perhaps from $100,000 for a family down to $80,000 and, in the following budget, down to $60,000. That is why we are seeking to introduce this automatic indexation, so the real value is maintained in real terms. That is the debating point. I have one question on this issue. It is the same one that we put before. Given those concerns, is the government planning to change those income thresholds for the Medicare levy?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.48 p.m.)We cannot accept these amendments. Again, the effect, as I am informed, would be a net of $35 million over the last two financial years of the four-year forward estimates. Of course there would be nothing in 1997-98 as a base year and we are not able, at short notice, to determine what it would be in I 998-99-but probably very little. I accept the shadow minister's comment that, yes, we could bring in a proposal at the next budget, but of course that would be subject to legislation. It would be something that we would have to debate in this House and in the other place and it would have to be passed by the parliament. Any concept of trying to sneak something through or have something happen without scrutiny would be impossible. Were we to do that, that would be something that the House and the Senate would have to consider and make a decision on. I would just comment that the limit here is a family income of $100,000, which is a very large family income-probably for the shadow minister as well as myself. That would apply to only about 1.5 to 2 per cent of the people I represent in the seat of Chisholm. This is something that does not affect a lot people. Any change that we were to make on this would have to be made as part of the next budget. I obviously cannot rule things in or out of the next budget, except to say that if we were to consider such a thing we would be fairly unwise to consider it before we had even passed this piece of legislation.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: I do not want to labour this. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) does seem to be leaving open the possibility of reducing the threshold in the next budget. I suppose any minister can say anything is possible, but I would be keen to know if the that government is planning any changes at the moment.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.50 p.m.)Having been in government himself, I hope the shadow minister has some sympathy for me. I am afraid that it is not possible to rule things in and out sequentially of what might be in the budget, except to say that, were we to consider that, there is no way we could do it other than through legislation and through due consideration in this place.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: I hope I am not misunderstanding the minister, but he seems to be leaving open the clear possibility that this threshold is reduced in the budget. If that is the case, then obviously he is giving me the opportunity to make sure that the Australian people know that that is a clear possibility come the May budget. If the government has no plans to change the thresholds, then I will accept that assurance.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.51 p.m.)This is the final attempt. I am simply doing what the previous government themselves did for 13 years and not rule budget speculation in or out. It only fuels speculation and makes it harder for me, if I do not draw the line at all suggestions, not to rule certain things in or out. I am afraid that I cannot do it. That is what the opposition, when in government, for 13 years followed themselves. I am doing nothing different.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: In the Senate, Senator Ellison, the Parliamentary of Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, did actually use those words in considering a number of amendments to the opposition's amendments. Senator Neal asked whether he could guarantee that the government would not be lowering the thresholds. At 6.26 p.m - on my understanding of the debate-he said that 'the government has no plans to do that'. The Hansard continued: Senator Neal-I actually missed that response.

Speaker: Senator ELLISON
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: You asked whether the government intended to reduce the threshold. I said that the government has no plans to do that. Senator Neal-Does that mean that you are prepared to give an undertaking that they will not?

Speaker: Senator ELLISON
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: I think I have answered the question as well as I can. So on two occasions Senator Ellison said that the government had no plans to lower the thresholds. Given that the minister has very skilfully avoided saying that in the House, I would be grateful if he would repeat the assurance that Senator Ellison gave the Senate-and if he will not, why not?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.53 p.m.)In the spirit of the courtesy that the opposition is showing in facilitating the passage of these pieces of legislation, I am really going to make this my last contribution. I congratulate Senator Ellison on being a new parliamentary secretary, and when he has been around a little bit longer he will learn how to answer the question. Question resolved in the affirmative.
